text: I rewatch these every few years, just to see a master at his craft. I think it works so well because he's incredibly funny, but matches it to his passion, which is 100% real. What is so sad is that predictions made 30 years ago are happening: we're seeing it right in front of us. And these criminal fossil companies are still using their surrogates to block progress. Even now, the Texas Governor is blaming the grid shutdowns on wind farms failing - which provide 7% of Texas power in winter - completely ignoring that the bulk of the grid power source systems have failed due to the freezing of the gas valves on the pipes to the power plants. Even the Texan power companies admit all the source power systems failed: nuclear, coal, and gas. Meanwhile, up in Canada, with a grid far more dependent on renewables, everything is running nicely. It's called "investment, engineering and management".

text:
I remember when this took place, I was in continental Europe at the time, somewhere in southern France, for work and studies.   And i recall that it was all over french news for a couple of days, as they really just could not believe how willfully ignorant these government officials were when it came to climate change and global warming. 
People outside of the U.S. were just astonished...         
I remember when the host played clips from this same event on national t.v., and the main guests; some minister from the french conservative LREM party, and a climate activist from  green EELV party, actually both laughed because they truely thought that it was satire! The host then tried to explain, and the conservative still wasn't having it. He started defending the American conservative movement, by comparing it to the French equivalent, and referencing original conservative principles etc... 
But then the other guest caught on and said "-Oh, but the American conservatives are different, their movement is full of religious extremists who embrace 17th century superstitions and reject science... what we're seeing is really happening over there, it's quite unbelievable isn't it? In the 21st century, in the world's leading super power! "  The conservative minister and the  t.v. host end up agreeing with  the member of the green  party that America was in the process of losing all credibility in the eyes of the world, and that due to a growing overt distain for critical thinking, poor education, and rampant conspiratorial obscurantism, the U.S.A. was no longer in a position to be taken seriously on positions such as climate change, energy development, or progress in the public sector.  
At the time  I remember thinking "That's a bit harsh!" And telling myself how it's probably just a phase that American politics we're going through... that eventually people would get a grip, and cooler heads would prevail, and America would end up leading the way into the new era of renewable energy and responsible production... 
How completely and utterly, very, very WRONG was I !?!?!  üòÇ üòÇ üòÇ üòß 
Barely a decade later, and the U.S.A is a global laughing stock, whilst in the grips of a violent proto-fascist movement, with a ridiculous orange authoritarian wanabe dictator at the helm of the nation, and who defines "Truth" as "whatever makes him feel good about himself at any given moment in time".......üò®

text:
Essentially, human pollution consisting of several distinct large and complex gaseous molecules escaping into the upper atmosphere (not the CO2 and other gasses remaining at ground level and used as plant food) but transition into the  upper atmosphere are not to be added to Total Solar Energetic Irradiance results and understood together. The contributions of total solar irradiance (TSI) heating are enormous especially when compared with human pollution contributions and interactions based on face value assessments of subjective observations. The combination of the two are meaningful and significant but not for purposes of this conversation. The human contribution is dwarfed when viewed in this way but not insignificant. 
Solar activity should initially be accessed separately over the long term and planet wide in order to fully understand and estimate its impact on its own. Human contributions to Global Warming/Climate Change must be studied separate from and calculated IN ADDITION to Solar Heating.
Second is human pollution climate forcing observations and assessments compiled over a long period of time and planet wide and must always be understood as a force IN ADDITION TOO total solar irradiance? That is pollution forces and interactions impact our planet and how do these numbers influence TSI? What are the long term effects of one on the other and visa versa? 
I do appreciate all of your efforts but I fear you are blinded by the forest and missing the tree, seeing the forest first from every subsequent perspective. Although it is important to include all of variables in any assessment of science phenomena we must be vigilant to fully access each component separate from all others first in order to gain an understanding of the effects of one on the other and visa-versa. Additionally, the effects of ground level gasses have nothing to do with aerial compound and large molecule gasses escaping into the upper atmosphere.
Additionally in accessing solar energetics electromagnetics and other planetary interactions including reactions another aspect underreported in all S0 videos is to account for outgoing solar energetics. Ben your work in describing total solar irradiance , climate Forcing, weather creation and patterning, wind cell patterning, terrestrial and atmospheric electrical and magnetic patterning including associated phenomena etc. etc. is insightful and appreciated. It might be important to include reflected energy losses including beginning in the upper atmosphere where earths‚Äô magnetosphere diverts accumulating 1200-4500 degree direct and radiated solar heating around and past the earth. As the majority of solar energy is swept away and around/diverted away from earth with it goes a long list of upper atmospheric charged particles, gaseous ions etc. rising and joining with departing solar wind charged particles etc it attaches to through the forces of inductive charging, cohesion and adhesion, electromagnetics, surface tension and the like cyclical activities, thereby pulls at the rising and thinning Earth atmosphere. If in fact the Earth was blanketed with a static energy of any type the effect in this case would then produce an increasingly dense and increasingly warmer atmosphere etc.  
The effects of complex, large molecule, upper atmosphere pollution gasses and their effects are always additive. Their accumulating in the upper atmosphere (doubling in number every 25 years) absorbing and reflecting direct incoming solar heat and reflecting and absorbing outgoing radiated solar heat are always tabulated/compounded after the effects of Direct total solar irradiance are calculated. Human impact is added on top of TSI or in addition to TSI.
The NASA video linked below shows several important considerations always critical in scientific observations. Perspective is as ever an important consideration. The video seemingly shows global warming expanding from Earths axial northern pole first and expanding into more temperate climate areas.

text:
Why is it people stop thinking once they get to a word they either agree or disagree with?
The ice in a cup argument only applies to ice currently resting in sea water.  
However, run the math on what ice rests on land. 
Oddly, one will find those numbers to be rather low in comparison. Only about 10% of Earth's land is covered by ice.
That leaves 90% not talked about.
The 10% WILL cause sea level to rise without a doubt.
The important unanswered question is "By what level will the water rise?"
We'll lose coast land for sure. 
Richies will have to move inland a mile or so. Big whoop.
There will be no more New Orleans and most of southern Florida will be underwater. Again, big whoop. 
With some land losses elsewhere on Earth.
My concern is, what the Earth will do to counter the CO2 rise. Earth always wins the co2 fight, usually at the cost of species living on it. 
Soon as Earth eliminates the source of the rising co2 (humans), it will once again return to it's resting state. A balance of co2, nitrogen, and oxygen. 
Actually, I am unsure what may happen to oxygen levels. If plants survive, it may remain at breathable levels. 

(It's NOT what we do. It IS however, the amount of people doing it which is the problem.)

text: If you know how greenhouse gases work, the science of climate change is a no brainer. Carbon gases exist naturally in our atmosphere and keep us warm by trapping heat! The hard part is getting people to understand that hotter planet means a variety of things, not just droughts and rising sea levels, but warming ocean currents, worse hurricanes, faster changes in weather patterns and extinction of a huge number of flora and fauna species that cannot adapt quickly enough to these changes and their effects. A lot of people just can't accept that human beings could have that much influence on the planet. Like we somehow haven't already molded a huge amount of its landscape for our purposes and literally in our image.

text: Back in the day when I was dressing mannequins, we had to secure the bases so they wouldn't fall over because our boss would get really mad if the mannequins fell over and got smashed or something. It was really stressful then, because the mirror clips would always break and he was a stickler for finding broken mirror clips. OMG, I have to stop and listen to some music because my parietal lobe is oozing with that moldy matter that causes Alzheimers, because I can't believe I have such a bad memory and can't remember things. Shit, is someone experimenting with my brain, without asking me? Do I have a chip in there making me smarter as I get older? Scary thought right? I heard of this thing called MKUltra, but I thought it was antifreeze. But you had to use 4, not 3, but 4 clips per base (unless it was a round base since 4 were too many to fit and round bases were sturdier anyway) I just made that last part up. I really can't remember a thing.
author: Robin Morgenweck

text: It musta snowed that day. Oh my God, where I used to work, if you didn't show up to work when you were sick or dying, you didn't get paid. Because after you fall on your face and get a melanoma, no is it a glaucoma, or a swollen jaw filled with blood and puss ( I can't remember the name) but You show up at work looking like THAT cause you need the money and don't get paid when you fall and hurt yourself, but you look too scary to the customers, no, wait, I think it bothered my supervisors more. text: I don't have a problem with commentators on the left or the right, who state their viewpoints explicitly and then try to defend those viewpoints.   Rachel Maddow, Chris Matthews, Rush Limbaugh and their ilk all have their faults, but they approach debate in an honest manner. That would even include O'Reilly, even though he interrupts and is rude and occasionally namecalls.  Stewart's comedy, in contrast, always begins with a Strawman Argument of his ideological opponent's viewpoint, which he then proceeds to bash with an Appeal to Ridicule, and then top off with an Ad Hominem attack.  His show is funny, he;s a great entertainer, but he also is a propagandist in the truest sense of the word, and he does a great disservice to our democracy.

text:
In the interests of accuracy, this is not true.  Ice is less dense than water (hence floating) so when the bit of ice below the surface melts, it takes up less space.  The 'gap' this leaves is exactly filled by the melted water from the ice that was above the surface level.

This is what that absolute feckwit in the video was thinking of.  Ice displaces water equal to its weight.  When the ice melts it becomes water equal to its weight, hence there is no change in the sea level.

As Jon Sterwart points out, he was not thinking of the ice that is not already in the water.  Because he's either a monumental idiot, or a hired shill.

text:
What is so very irritating is that carbon emissions is not the reason it seems hotter.  Now listen, the Ozone is now depleted to the extent that there is not enough of it to diffuse (scatter) the suns rays as they pass through the atmosphere thereby heating the surface in a more direct fashion.  Proofs of this come easy, for one the sun at midday is a very bright xenon white in color as compared to the school bus yellow appearance that it was in the 1970's.  Also one just has to feel the temperature difference on the skin between sun and shade. Materials left outdoors are now breaking down at a much higher rate than they did some 20~40 years ago (same materials, same quality and construction). 
     You see when the suns rays pass through a dense layer of ozone those rays are scattered in all directions, a direct result of this scattering changes the appearance of the sun to a yellow ~ yellow/orange color when viewed at noontime from the ground.
     There were many experiments done in the 1970's and before to find the most efficient means of reducing the ozone layer above the polar regions. This was done in hopes of melting the ice so that the vast natural resources can be accessed. Unfortunately this ozone layer depletion goal failed to keep the effects localized over the poles as was hoped.   Several of these experiments were done from the skylab space station back in the 70's, several types of aerosols were tested to see in real time how effective they were at dissolving the ozone layer. The skylab experiments are documented and can be found online from a dot gov website, although it takes a lot of digging the documented evidence is there for all to see, It also shows where/who the push for this depletion originates.  So it actually doesn't take much thought to be able to see the big picture of this global warming deception.  If you will only do the research you will see that all that I said is indeed the true reality in which we now live.
author: orange70383

text:
with all due respect to stewart, who i love watching like no one else... but the argument put forward about scientists whose careers do not depend on actual empirical facts but rather on prior to conduct of any data measurement/analysis defined outcomes.... it sort of got distorted by Stewart making it about complaining that scientists are doing what they do because it's their profession rather than their hobby...
I'm not defending that guy on the issue of climate change, but on the line of reasoning...
I've already seen a bit of scientific conduct when it comes to peer-reviewed publication and competition among scientists... 
and there are two major problems arising within that system:
1. measurement data gets cooked by either discarding subsets of the data  or actually manipulating numbers) in order to prevent unwanted outcomes. 
(for example, if you made a career on certain beliefs and you find experimental indication/evidence against, you could question your entire life's work and career by publishing it.... Or another possibility is that funding of research is biased towards the specific results you produce... If you know what scientific results are expected of you, you are inclined to make sure your future funding is secured by providing the political consensus)
2. in so called social sciences (like economics) ideology plays an even bigger role... Not just funding is an objective influencing the scientific focus and outcomes of peer-reviewed papers in journals. It will become impossible to even publish in the first place (not just dealing with the consequences of what your scientific findings say about reality). The bias in mainstream peer-reviewed economics is so strong that any effort to bring in some fresh ideas and approaches into the scientific community are nipped in the bud before they even get the chance to be seen (let alone reviewed) by somebody interested in it.
I see phd students reviewing paper about topics where they do not even know the basics about, let alone possess any specific knowledge, just because their thesis supervisor delegated his/her work. And even if these professors did it themselves. Often times they too do not understand what the paper is about.... 

The peer-reviewed system itself is highly flawed and just because some right-wing nutjobs do not trust science in general, doesn't mean any scientific conduct and the system itself is flawless

text:
I always find that argument hilarious coming from politicians. Essentially they're saying money corrupts, and it's impossible for a scientist to get paid for doing their job without it representing or causing a conflict. Well if money is such a corrupting influence, how about we make it a law that no politician gets any money, ever? After all, nothing they do (mostly standing or sitting in a room) really costs anything, certainly not compared to scientists, who need expensive technical equipment and access to data, field stations and hiring assistants and students. And what costs they do incur, we already subsidise anyway on top of their regular pay, unlike scientists who usually foot their own costs out of their salaries.

Conservative US politicians like talking about getting rid of entitlement and people pulling themselves up by their bootstraps; well how about we get rid of their entitlements and perks and anything that could make them complacent or corrupt, and make sure they do their jobs the way they would like us to do ours? The hard way, and for minimal cost. It would be the honest thing to do. And while we're at it, why not hold politicians to the same honesty standards as we do scientists? If a scientist is caught plagiarising or falsifying data even slightly, they get forced to resign. How about when a politician makes a false claim which doesn't appeal to the verified facts, they get sacked? I think that's just fair.

text: ¬†@Levity¬†¬†It most definitely is a form corruption in my eyes, man. I.e; 'Big Corp' gives 2 mill to get "Bill the Politician" elected. text:

author: Levity

text: ¬†@Levity¬† There is a separation here. Donating to political parties is ok, but donating to individual candidates is not in my opinion. In Norway, and I assume most of Europe, you can only donate to the party itself. The process is very open. The companies/rich people donating usually tell the press. Therefore, the donations work towards pushing the party general values, rather than single policies big corps want.

text:
Climate scientists don't need there to be climate change for them to continue publishing. They have doctorates. Does this guy not realize that having Ph.D.s in advanced chaos math means you're qualified to do more than check a thermometer?

More to the point, their professional reputations are riding on the accuracy of their findings and the rigor of their methodology. They have strong economic incentives to tell the truth about what they find, because if they don't it'll bite them in the ass. Further, if it turns out that their methodology is good and their findings meaningfully disagree with those of their colleagues, they'll get Nobel prizes.

Do you not get that, congressman? If they disprove the current theories of climate that means they will be paid exponentially more money and get a hell of a lot more respect. We know about Einstein, not because he published a bunch of papers about how Newtonian physics made sense, but because he came up with explanations for Newtonian inconsistencies and completely revolutionized his field.

So, if a climate scientist is doing research into global warming, they're doing that research hoping to find evidence that it's either not happening, or can be explained by something people haven't considered before. Their incentive is to disprove climate change. However, the fact that you don't know any climate scientist's names means that none of them have been successful to any meaningful degree.

How little does this guy understand science and academia?

text: To 64cl, speaking as an "ingnoramus" (sic?) so described, I believe I might shed light on your curiosity as to how some of us see fit to reject the current conclusions of the greater climate science  field yet also embrace the fruits of scientific discovery and innovation. Many of us come from backgrounds in science and from families of Ph.D. scientists from top programs. We've become unsteady, on might put it, with swallowing the blue pill because virtually no one  in our long lineage of earnest research has ever embraced a conclusion as rabidly as have the current champions of MMGW. To wit, I know well three Ivy League  Ph.D.s in climatology who all acknowledge never questioning the conclusions before enrolling in their doctoral programs. Upon questioning, all admit never having been, through their programs, immersed or exposed to any contrarian professionals  thoughts on the issue. One confesses to being uncomfortable with, as he termed it, the "Orwellian groupthink" of the classes.

text:
But a lot of people also swallow things like how gravity works without questioning it - simply because there is no need to question it - why waste more time trying to disprove established science? If you have failed to notice, scientists have already wasted a lot of money trying to disprove that human emissions are the cause of the global warming because contrariants (or ignoramuses which I call them) keep demanding proof. The proof has actually been around for at least since Svante Arrhenius showed that CO2 will cause global warming over 100 years ago. But it was actually the air force that brought the science to the next level in understanding exactly how the CO2 molecule works. So your Ph.D. friends, do they actually read any of this established science and how we know it to be a fact by now, or are they starting from the assumption that everything discovered up to now can be false, hence we dont need to believe any science. I'd certainly not want to go to any of those Ph.D's for scientific advice as they would be as good as a fortune teller or other quack. Ph.D. isnt just about getting a piece of paper with your degree - its about actually understanding what you read to get it. I'd like to see the Ph.D. degree on global-warming-is-a-hoax...

I like to ask all people this question to see if they are at least lukewarm: Do you agree that CO2 is a greenhouse gas, and do you understand the molecules properties? Do you recognize the fact that without the little CO2 we already have (risen from 280ppm to 400ppm past 100 years though) the earths average temperature would be -18C, in other words a complete ice ball (has happened in earths history as well).
author: 64jcl

text: Climatologists who so exuberantly come forth with pronouncements and data may indeed pile on effectively. After all, who is left with any credence that the menschs haven't managed to professionally destroy? That was never the manner  honest science in the past 450 years. To think that a field so astonishingly young as climatology would so quickly become the jealous terrain of political insult and unquestioned groupthink tells and student of evidence-based thought that this whole endeavor has, for now, been corrupted. When the pros of this field acknowledge what happened with one of their own foundational programs, East Anglia, then we can start to trust the data. Not when they read on some MMGW friendly site a biased summation of how it's irrelevant. When they read the emails themselves and say, "That's unconscionable and any defense of it is completely unacceptable." Many of us hope for the day we can listen to the data without feeling the obligation to question motives so vigorously.
author: jrneobliviscaris

text:
+sarcastic bowl of cornflakes
"Climate scientists don't need there to be climate change for them to continue publishing."

Let's just focus our point here, even though the excellent points made below it should also be highlighted. We just can't move on without accepting that fact.
Science isn't a simple market where you can label the knowledge you sell as a product to your audience whether it's a scientific committee or others. If either a new hypothesis, studied theory or accepted laws experience a change it's not a simple matter of every single scientist in the relevant field suddenly lose their jobs or their knowledge becomes irrelevant.

It's really hard to explain from there so instead I think I should reduce my intelligence to the accepted relevant level and propose a conspiracy theory. See, the House Committee of Science, Space and Technology is still governed by politicians. Politicians will use everything within their power to their advantage and either protect their position or fight for what's likely to be most profitable to them. They understand their audience a little better than those nerds in white coats and will communicate their argument in a language that suits the audience best, and the audience understands the concept of having no product means you're out of business. In this case, if there's no climate change then there's no need for climatologists. It's right in their name after all, right? Considering that it's the people who hold the power (or that's what they want you to assume but one conspiracy theory at a time) and the people will see that the climatologist is talking out of his ass, you've successfully disproved climate change despite all facts and evidence to the contrary.

Consider some of their other arguments. Public comments? Displacement? Scare tactics? "I understand that, therefore it must be true!" It really doesn't matter if a few of the smarter folk catch on, they're the minority after all, and you just need the majority to understand your language and your side.

text: +Phil Buckhouse I don't think there was originally term limits for presidents. That is why Roosevelt had like 4 terms. No one before him was either insane enough or popular enough to want/get the job a third time. There are now term limits on the presidency, obviously, though because congress passed an amendment that ratified that as part of the constitution. Unsurprisingly, they have not limited their own power by placing term limits on themselves. So yeah.
author: Jojo Delacroix

text: +John Edwards Interestingly, the de facto two-term limit that was around pre-FDR was a combination of both nobody wanting the job that long (an old social studies teacher of mine had a poster with pictures of the first 42 presidents with quotes from them all about how awful being the president is, I need to find that), and also a holdover of tradition because Washington wouldn't take a third term. There are a lot of things about the presidency that came about because it's what Washington did, and everyone is just following his lead. For example, when the office of President was first created, people were proposing that the holder of the office be addressed as "your Majesty," and Washington was the one that said it sounded too regal, too monarchial. So they came up with "Mr. President." The Bible presidents are sworn in on, is still the one Washington used. And after Washington's second term, pretty much everybody wanted him to take a third term, and he declined. So all the presidents after that decided, if Washington wouldn't take a third term, neither will I. It took the combination of our country's worst ever depression followed immediately by a large-scale war in order to break that tradition.

text: I have to say something. Jon makes the point that scientists cannot be bought. Personally, being a student pf electrical engineering and computer science, i take great pride in the fact that the scientific community is very pure and noble. Yet i do believe that there are some of us who might get bought, but we choose our representatives due to merit, so they cannot be corrupted. The main difference between science and politics, is that in politics you can argue and come to different conclusions, and in the end rely on a statistical method such as voting, in order to take an action. This means that the truth in politics is not one but many, and they struggle to choose one that better represents their interests (as shown from the financial backers of this politicians). In science on the other hand, the truth is one and that is mathematically and experimentally proven, you cannot go around and deny facts, thus you cannot pay a scientist to lie.

text: I love how Steve Stockman tries to act like he's making valid points, with his "frustrated" hand gestures and the facial expression that says "c'mon guys, this is obvious." How do these people get on this committee? You would think they would at least know 5th grade science. Look at people in environment science! This science is an interdisciplinary field by nature - involving the natural and social sciences: chemistry, engineering, anthropology, political science, ecology, ethics, history, sociology, archeology, oceanography, biology, economics, geology, etc... My political science friends always say "oh, science is too difficult for me, I want nothing to do with that." Fine, not everyone needs to like or be an expert in science. But if a politician is going to be on the US House of Rep Committee on Science, Space, and Technology he needs to learn science...I mean people like Mr. Stockman needs to learn from environmentalists and environmental scientists. Environmental stewardship is important because our future children deserve a sustainable environment, too.

text: +Sierra Davis What the chairman was saying was that given the scale in which Global Wobbling affects the Earth's climate (at the earliest, on a scale of 22,000 years), that it is obsolete with regards to the 100 year-period addressed by the climate reports. Basic Science 101 for the kindergarteners out there.
Plants, unlike us, breath in CO2 and they expel O2 they we humans need very badly to live. The greener the plants, the better they are for us to eat. More CO2 also means more oxygen for us to breath making us all smarter in the long run, well everyone except for Democrats, Liberals, and anyone in a mental institution. Yes the temperature may be rising and it might be getting hotter, but MAN did not create this problem. It is just a fact of the planet that there is always a cooling and heating periods over time. author: wiet111

text: ¬†@*****¬†¬†Bernie is a democratic free market socialist. Not a communist. Get your fact straight,¬†
author: wiet111

text: ¬†@*****¬†¬†No, it is very different. What Bernie is proposing is a free democratic capitalist society which supports the poor. Communism is a system without ownership where the state controls everything. The two are very different. Bernie Sanders is aiming for basically the scandinavian model. Not communism.
author: wiet111

text:
¬†@*****¬†¬†No, there is ¬†a big difference. Socialism limits the taking to the level needed to provide good services to everybody and give everyone a good shot at having a good life. Once again, look up the scandinavian model. It works. The scandinavian countries are basically on every list you want to be on. Obviously it can't be copied to America directly, but redistributing some wealth and spending more money on infrastructure, education, etcetera makes sense. Right now America's system is biased in favour of wealthy people. If you're rich, you can get richer quite easily. If you're poor, it's extremely hard to get out.¬†
I agree that complete communism doesn't work. Effort and talent needs to be rewarded. However, gving everybody good chances at a good life is important too.¬†

A question for you: Do you think that the government needs to pay for the medical bills of veterans who can't afford them themselves? If you agree you are also a socialist, but Bernie Sanders just goes a bit further. Just read his plans. He is not a communist, he just goes further than the current system.
author: wiet111

text:
¬†@*****¬†¬†First of all, what is your answer to my question about healthcare for veterans? If you honestly think that there should be no socialism in a state, you would not give poor veterans any healthcare. Is that actually what you think?
Furthermore, look at Europe. Scandinavian countries, or the Netherlands (With which I'm more familiar) are social democracies, and have been that for very long. They are not becoming communist, nor will they.

Basically, your entire argument against Bernie Sanders is just a slippery slope fallacy. You say that Bernie Sanders will lead to communism, while that is just an ubsubstantiated untrue assertion.¬†
author: wiet111

text:
¬†@*****¬†¬†I am not talking about how well it is being implemented, I am talking about the principle. Do the weakest links in the population deserve to be protected by those who can? If someone can't afford to go to school, should the government fund schools? This is redistribution of wealth, and therefore socialism. It's also a great thing.

Furthermore, I would like to ask you for any example of a social democratic capitalist system like for instance scandinavian countries or the Netherlands, that has led to communism. There is not such an example, because there is a difference. Communism is about equality of wealth. Socialism is about equality of chances.¬†

You continue to use your 'free stuff is better than freedom" nonsense, but the people in the countries I described are very free.¬†

To make my point entirely clear, I would like you to answer three hypothetical questions.
1: If a poor veteran can't pay their bills, should the government help them?
2: If a kid can't afford to go to school, should the government help him?
3: Are there any examples of social democracies that have turned into communist states?
author: wiet111

text:
¬†@*****¬†¬†I don't say that the current systems are perfect (Although not everything is being wasted).¬†

I know that there are safety nets now. That's because America is already a social democracy. It's just not very social. Sanders wants to make it more social. He doesn't want to fundamentally change America's economic system, but he wants to increase and improve what is already there. He wants the social state to get to the level of Scandinavia or the Netherlands, not beyond. That won't lead to communism, just like it doesn't happen in Europe.¬†

You seem to think that Sanders wants to nationalize the economy (he doesn't), make America communist (he doesn't) or fundamentally change the economic system of America (He doesn't).

What he wants is make it possible for the poor to move up the economy and have a decent life. I'm not agreeing with all of his policies, but I agree with the principles.¬†

Could you tell me which specific plans of Sanders would destroy the economy and ruin America, because so far it just seems like you are afraid of the word socialism and therefore of Sanders.¬†
author: wiet111

text:
¬†@*****¬†¬†That is a completely nonsensical argument. He wants to create more jobs, so less people have to be lazy. He wants to raise the minimum wage, so people who work can actually live of their work. He wants to make education affordable, so more people get the chance to learn and do better work. Admittedly, he wants to make healthcare cheaper, but Europe shows that that can actually save tons of money.¬†

Please just go to Bernie Sanders's website, and look at his plans. He wants to get companies and wealthy people who avoid taxes by for instance moving their official headquarters abroad to pay American taxes. He wants to raise the minimum wage. He wants to create jobs by investing in infrastructure. He wants to allow more people to go to university.¬†

If you think that Sanders wants to hand out free money to lazy people, give me evidence. All I can see (and his proposals and voting record support this) is that Bernie Sanders wants to give the lower and middle class people who work a more honest reward than what they are getting now. People still need to work for their money, but he wants to create more chances to work for their money.¬†

Once again, Sanders isn't perfect and I don't agree with everything he says. However, you are simply putting up strawman arguments which don't represent Sanders' ideas at all. Please do some research, and give well argued arguments why he is so bad.
author: wiet111

text:
¬†@*****¬†¬†Do you have any proof for this? The Scandinavian unemployment rate is comparable to the US. States that raised the minimum wage actually had a faster job growth. You make these allegations, but without evidence, they are completely worthless.
Also, flipping hamburgers shouldn't be a career, but we will continue to need people at different layers. We can't all be CEO's. Everybody, even the ones with the less impressive jobs, deserve to make a living wage if they work.
Sanders' version of socialism will indeed not make the US perfect. However, it also won't bury it.¬†

I might of course be wrong, but you haven't given me any proof. Show me some of his plans that are detrimental, and show me evidence for why they are bad. Don't claim that a social democracy is bad just because you say so.
author: wiet111

text: Yes yes yes!
author: James Smith

text:
¬†@*****¬†¬†Nobody is arguing for taking away all profits. There must be incentives to work. That doesn't mean that the richest 0.1% should own just as much as the poorest 90% combined.¬†
Obviously complete wealth-distribution won't work, but fairer wages and tazes definitely will. Once again, look at Northern Europe. Taxes are high, but people still have incentive to work.
author: wiet111

+Admiral Nimitz You're describing communism here, not socialism. Learn the fucking difference.


I live in France and the UK, and it's a lot closer to what Bernie Sanders wants to achieve.

author: Emil Curtis

text: ¬†@*****¬†¬†Do some proper research. France doesn't have a 75% tax (They wanted to at some point, but they got rid of it incredibly fast). Furthermore, France has a very inefficient government. Sanders is more aiming towards the Northern countries.
author: wiet111

text:
¬†@*****¬†¬†I completely agree that a 75% tax doesn't work. That's why France got rid of it so quickly. However, this was not the cause of the unemployment. Neither is the principle of socialism. France just has some incredibly inefficient institutions. Once again, the model that Sanders is defending is the Scandinavian model. They are doing great.¬†

I would like to ask you to look at Sanders' plans, and tell me with which ones you disagree specifically. Don't attack strawman arguments, attack the actual ideas of Sanders. (You can find his ideas on his website).
author: wiet111

text:
¬†@*****¬†¬†You keep on making all these claims, but they are just not based on facts. Northern European countries' productivity are very similar to that of the US (According to data from the OECD), and they are way more socialist.
Furthermore, these socialist countries consistently rank extremely high (higher than the US) on for instance measurements of happiness.¬†

Once again, me nor Bernie Sanders are arguing for taking away the reward for hard and competent work. However, perhaps the top 0.1% in America should not earn as much as the bottom 90%. Perhaps the state should take a bit more care of those who can't take care of themselves. Perhaps working people should have a living wage, independent of what type of job they're doing.

I feel like I'm starting to sound like a broken recordplayer, but you simply aren't responding to my comments but instead continue to put of strawman arguments and unsubstantiated statements.

Please have a look at the specific plans of Bernie Sanders and respond to them. Don't attack the concept of socialism how you see it, because that is irrelevant. While responding to his arguments, please use genuine sources.¬†
author: wiet111

text:
¬†@*****¬† No scientist is claiming that. There are records showing that there is a natural climate cycle. That does NOT however change the fact that our behavior is causing ENHANCED climate change, which is likely to happen more rapidly and with stronger impacts, due to the imbalance in the Carbon cycle we are causing.
And there is a difference between what you describe and climate. Climate occurs over decades and looks at averages, and if we look at those, there is a pretty clear trend of increase in temperature, increase in the magnitude and frequency of climate related natural disasters as well as effects of air and oceanic currents, which cause droughts, more natural disasters, etc.
Will this DESTROY OUR WORLD IN 5 YEARS like some people might claim? No, but fact is, that our behavior is not just harmful to the environment, but also impacts climate, which really should be avoided.

But the whole length of human civilization since the stone age is less than 0.0003% of the total time the Earth has existed. So everything, from the ancient Egyptians to the rise and fall of the Roman empire to the renaissance to the world wars has been insignificant when looking at such large timescales.¬†
What we do see now is that the climate is changing on a rate that hasn't happened in tens of thousands of years and we know what is the cause of that change. This climate change is happening on a time scale of decades to centuries and that is important for us.

author: masterrance

text:
¬†@masterrance¬†
Well again, there are certain conditions which need to be there for life. If we fuck up badly and cause a similar effect to that found in Venus, I highly doubt species could survive. And in any way, most certainly the more developed species will actually all fail, as they have far too long generation spans to evolve fast enough. Yes, bacteria or other microorganisms with very short generation spans might survive, but that doesnt mean they couldnt be wiped out, nor does it guarantee the formation of new developed species. Evolution is not so much a process with a drive, but more of a random process. There is no drive in a species that makes it evolve. It is purely based on a large population undergoing random mutations and the more suitable mutations being selected. If all life on earth boild down to one simplistic bacteria, there is no "drive" that makes this bacteria mutate more suitable features. It is something that could happen by random occurance, but there is no guarantee for it, just like there is no guarantee for that mutation to actually spread. It is simply assumed that it would happen eventually, as time passes by.

text:
¬†@kpetters¬† wo points:
1. There are many who are aware that water does not rise when ice melts. Unfortunately, the anti-global-warming side use this fact by twisting it in their campaign of dis-information. They are counting on most people knowing only a ‚Äúlittle‚Äù bit of science. Yes, it's true, that the ocean would not rise if the ice burgs in it were to melt. But here comes the point that John Stewart could only crudely allude to. Which is that this only applies to the north pole where the ice is already in the ocean. Were he in a position to elaborate, he'd say that the danger lies in what exists at the south pole. There you have a continent about the size of Australia. That continent is completely covered in ice that has the average thickness between two and a half to three miles. Now if that ice melts, it then leaves the land its sitting on and ends up in the ocean, thereby rising the sea levels.
¬†Now as to how high the sea rises? I've heard reports that range anywhere from 3 to 300 feet. I honestly don't know which is accurate but suffice it to say, that it really does not matter. Even the best case scenario of 3 feet would still be considered catastrophic. Think about it, there are cities around the globe that are highly prone to flooding when hurricanes happen. IE: New Orleans. Other places like Holland, have huge dams to keep the ocean back. Now New Orleans has devices to measure the oceans rise and fall to within a quarter of an inch. If they feel that such a small amount of change is worthy of measuring, imagine what 3 feet would mean to them.
¬†Approximately eighty to ninety percent of the worlds population live by the worlds oceans I believe. Were the ocean to rise to catastrophic levels, it would not happen in a heart beat but very quickly all the same. As a result, there would be over an extremely short time frame, a mass exodus inland into other cities ill equipped to handle the sudden influx. Mass economic turmoil, food, medical, and housing crises would be the immediate result. With more pain to follow.

author: Edward Dongres

text:
¬†@Edward Dongres¬† 
Increase in atmospheric CO
2 since the Industrial Revolution.
The warming trend following the Last Glacial Maximum, since about 20,000 years ago, has resulted in a sea level rise by about 130 metres. This warming trend has subsided about 6,000 years ago, and sea level has been comparatively stable since the Neolithic. The present interglacial period (the Holocene) has been fairly stable and warm, but the previous one was interrupted by numerous cold spells lasting hundreds of years. If the previous period was more typical than the present one, the period of stable climate, which allowed the Neolithic Revolution and by extension human civilization, may have been possible only because of a highly unusual period of stable temperature.

Based on orbital models, the cooling trend initiated about 6,000 years ago will continue for another 23,000 years. Slight changes in the Earth's orbital parameters might however indicate that, even without any human contribution, there will not be another glacial period for the next 50,000 years. It is possible that the current cooling trend may be interrupted by an interstadial in about 60,000 years, with the next glacial maximum reached only in about 100,000 years.

Based on past estimates for interglacial durations of about 10,000 years, in the 1970s there was some concern that the next glacial period would be imminent. However, slight changes in the eccentricity of Earth's orbit around the Sun suggest a extended interglacial for about 50,000 years. Additionally, human impact is now seen as possibly delaying what would already be an unusually long warm period. Projection of the timeline for the next glacial maximum depend crucially on the amount of CO
2 in the atmosphere. Models assuming increased CO
2 levels at 750 parts per million (ppm; current levels are at 407 ppm) have estimated the persistence of the current interglacial period for another 50,000 years.However, more recent studies concluded that due to the amount of heat trapping gases emitted into Earth's Oceans and atmosphere, that this will prevent the next glacial (ice age), which otherwise would begin in around 50,000 years, and likely more glacial cycles.

The charts that are peer reviewed and substantiated by 97% of climate and meteorological scientists can be found here.....
https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/52/Carbon_History_and_Flux_Rev.png

text: ¬†@I Am The Law¬†¬†I read an interesting study done on ideology in America. ¬†The investigators gave pretty strong support for the idea that liberalism and conservatism are not on opposite ends of the same spectrum. ¬†The reason I bring this up is because it is not that one group is more correct than another, we just have different interpretations of the terms conservative and liberal. ¬†That is, most people identifying as conservative would probably cite capitalism and a need for stability and order as the most important aspects of their positive attitude toward conservatism. ¬†They wouldn't be 'wrong' per se considering how well capitalism has worked for us (not saying it is a perfect economic system though), and there are obvious benefits to having structure and order in a nation. Whereas liberals will often cite a need for social justice and change; the pressing economic and racial disparities we have not resolved as the basis for their ideological identification. Both groups have legitimate cases; it's just a matter of what you consider to be most important to the success of a nation. Personally, I think our failures to recognize true egalitarianism among races, genders, and sexual minorities is disgusting and cannot be something we can disregard, especially considering its current symptoms in the form of police brutality, prejudice against sexual minorities, etc. ¬†But I am not going to reject capitalism and the need to moderate the size of our government either..

text:
Two points:
1. There are many who are aware that water does not rise when ice melts. Unfortunately, the anti-global-warming side use this fact by twisting it in their campaign of dis-information. They are counting on most people knowing only a ‚Äúlittle‚Äù bit of science. Yes, it's true, that the ocean would not rise if the ice burgs in it were to melt. But here comes the point that John Stewart could only crudely allude to. Which is that this only applies to the north pole where the ice is already in the ocean. Were he in a position to elaborate, he'd say that the danger lies in what exists at the south pole. There you have a continent about the size of Australia. That continent is completely covered in ice that has the average thickness between two and a half to three miles. Now if that ice melts, it then leaves the land its sitting on and ends up in the ocean, thereby rising the sea levels.
	Now as to how high the sea rises? I've heard reports that range anywhere from 3 to 300 feet. I honestly don't know which is accurate but suffice it to say, that it really does not matter. Even the best case scenario of 3 feet would still be considered catastrophic. Think about it, there are cities around the globe that are highly prone to flooding when hurricanes happen. IE: New Orleans. Other places like Holland, have huge dams to keep the ocean back. Now New Orleans has devices to measure the oceans rise and fall to within a quarter of an inch. If they feel that such a small amount of change is worthy of measuring, imagine what 3 feet would mean to them.
	Approximately eighty to ninety percent of the worlds population live by the worlds oceans I believe. Were the ocean to rise to catastrophic levels, it would not happen in a heart beat but very quickly all the same. As a result, there would be over an extremely short time frame, a mass exodus inland into other cities ill equipped to handle the sudden influx. Mass economic turmoil, food, medical, and housing crises would be the immediate result. With more pain to follow.


2. Even if the south pole did not exist and we only had to concern ourselves with the melting of the north pole there would still be world wide climatic consequences. How? Were that ice to melt it would affect the path of the worlds ocean conveyor. ‚ÄúWhat's that?‚Äù you might be asking. Well you've no doubt heard of the jet stream. The ocean conveyor is the oceans version of the jet stream. And it is this conveyor that actually determines how the jet stream behaves. The effects of the ice melting are already being felt. As one example, look at tornado alley in the United States. With each passing year the size of it is increasing. It's beginning further south and stretching further north. Wider to the east and west too. Not only that but it's starting earlier in the season and running later too. The number of tornadoes reported has increased as well as there sizes and wind speeds and even how many are touching down at the same time.

Another very important point; those previous warming periods show a warming trend of about 2 deg in 1000-3000 years, while today's warming has a trend of 1-2 C per century. So, the warming we're seeing today is happening at a much faster rate that past warming periods.

author: Edward Dongres

text:
¬†@Edward Dongres¬†

>>1) I put no confidence to any single source. But few thousand scientists will do.

Then why are you so certain that the MWP and the Holocene maximum where MUCH warmer than todays temperatures?

>>2) So what increased CO2 levels during Holocene Maximum? And what decreased them? The fact is CO2 levels lags behind temperatures - sometimes, and sometimes no relation at all.¬†

I already answered this, but again: the coming and going of glacial periods is the result of Milankovitch cycles. Imagine the Earth is in an ice age. Then changes in the Earth's orbit will cause the Earth to receive more solar radiation, so the Earth will get warmer. Warmer oceans can't dissolve as much CO2 as colder oceans, so this warming will cause oceans to release CO2. Because of the greenhouse effect, this increase in atmospheric CO2 will cause more warming, which results in more outgassing of CO2. It's called a positive feedback.
At one point the¬†Milankovitch cycles will result in less solar radiation and the Earth will cool, this cooling causes the oceans to absorb more CO2 and the whole process is reversed.
The Holocene maximum is just the maximum temperature during this interglacial. At that point the¬†Milankovitch cycles and the whole CO2 feedback process have reversed and for the last couple of thousand years the Earth has been moving into a next ice age.

When exactly has there been no relation between CO2 and temperature?

>>4) How do you know when there is and isn't a thread of Ice Age?Ôªø

Because of studies on previous ice ages we know that an ice age wont happen overnight, but it is the result of a very slow cooling process (slow from our perspective). So we know that it will still take a couple of thousand years of cooling for the Earth to get into a next ice age.

text:
¬†@Edward Dongres¬† here's a pretty comprehensive site: http://climate.nasa.gov. Please, if there's something that doesn't make sense to you try to find an actual scientist to explain, don't ask in a youtube comments section where most people (including myself) can't really grasp all the nuances of the climate change literature.

I will concede that I'm not that into the scientific knowledge to be able to answer your challenges to the theory, but the basics are there for me to not think about it as much. Mainly: 

- There's a consensus of 96% of scientists that climate change is mostly due to human activity (as reported in Last Week Tonight), even though here in Europe there has been general consensus for some years now.
- The basic explanation makes sense to me: CO2 makes possible a warmer atmosphere than if there wasn't any, CO2 emissions have risen a lot, therefore the average global temperature is rising consistently (not every year, but on a bigger timescale). 
- This makes the climate be more extreme, not just warmer: the example that made sense to me was that when in summer there's a really hot day, the next days more and more water have evaporated leading to massive rains and a big drop in the temperature ‚Äî but again, I don't have enough scientific knowledge to know if this example is consistent with reality.
- There seems to be much more economic interest on disproving climate change on the side of Carbon and Oil industry than the other way.

These are all points that drive me to believe in what the Science says enough that I don't need to nitpick every occurrence that seems to go against the climate change narrative, which is by the way called anecdotal evidence. 
Mainly: there is by far more evidence to support human-made climate change exists than the other way around.

text:
¬†@Ivar Tangen¬†¬†I'd say all three, but lack of education would be the primary. Many people don't do critical thinking, and they selectively see things that confirm their existing conclusions. So it is really hard to tell those people what we found in lab. And the academia can be way more competitive than the industry, so we really don't have lots of time and energy for conversations going nowhere... But if someone is willing to see things logically, we are very happy to share and don't mind the time at all.
Plus our publications have no juicy eyeball-grabing headlines, so people get bored quickly. (This one is on us. Researchers need to balance story-telling and scientific rigorousness.)


What worries me also is while middle-school education is watered down, college education is turning into vocational education. People laugh at the bleak job market for liberal arts majors, while good liberal arts education provides the broad range of knowledge and fundamental reasoning skills for a intellectually free person. As an STEM major, some of my peers' lack of knowledge outside their immediate field is appalling, which of course prevents them from promoting their results to a boarder audience. We get Bachelor's on science, but do we really know where science comes from, how the methodology evolves, and what its limits are? Or is the diploma merely a ticket to big tech companies? Even as we get the Doctor of Philosophy degree, how many of us know about natural philosophy, the ultimate pursuit of understanding nature and bettering human life? Or are we just a bunch of nerds solving crazily complex equations?

To be fair, it has been quite easy to talk with STEM majors outside my field and liberal arts folks. They are trained in reasoning after all. Those who ridicule both STEM and liberal arts are the worst.

text: There's a fundamental misunderstanding that is at the heart of this debate. ¬†Ice which is water in the the solid phase does not have the same density as liquid water. ¬†It's a peculiar quality of H2O that when it passes to into a solid state (frozen) that it's density is less than its liquid state. ¬†This effect is not observed with any other compound upon which life on our planet depends. ¬†It is vital to us and to all life on earth that water behaves in this peculiar way. ¬†Why is there ice on the surface of a pond, a lake, a river while beneath the ice, water is still in its liquid state where fish etc survive season after season? ¬†Because when water freezes, unlike other compounds, it becomes LESS dense. ¬†That is WHY LIFE EXISTS ON EARTH. ¬†That is why when the ice melts, we are not talking about a 1-to-1 ratio of distribution of melted ice to liquid water. ¬†Ice floats on top. ¬†When it melts, it is not less in volume than when it froze, it is the same; in fact it will in liquid state regain its liquid density.

text:
¬†@Edward Dongres¬† Science never claims to be 100% sure about anything. Because it proves things by trying to disprove them if them, if it cant those things are assumed to be correct. They become our best guess and as such the accepted scientific theory. Its possible even for some new evidence to emerge that would even change everything we know about gravity.

That is just how science works, at any time anything could be proven wrong by new evidence. That does not mean however that you should ignore science.

It tells you what our best guess is. Even if we are only 99.99999% sure about it as is the case with things like the theory of gravity or evolution. Decisons should then be made on the evidence of what our best guess is.

That is just how reason and logic work. We can never be 100% sure about anything because we can never know for certain that we have all the evidence about anything.

That does not mean the house is right to challenge science however. Just because their is a chance they could be wrong. They are ignoring the best guess of science. When a volcano explodes that it can causes temperatures to go down. Although it released CO2 it also released ash. Which in the short term blocks out the sunlight. That ash will eventually in a few months come out of the air in rain. While the CO2 may take hundreds or thousands of years to be absorbed into the ocean or rocks. So the short term result of a volcano erupting is the average global temperature go down but the long term result is that temperatures go up.

Its much the same with some cases of pollution. The issue isnt a simple one.

text:
¬†@Edward Dongres¬†¬†Alright. Let me try to give you a broad overview - which I hope you will listen to. 

There are these gases which are "green house gases" - i.e. their molecules help retain the heat within our atmosphere. It is a good thing - because otherwise we would be a colder place - inhospitable for life. But since the industrial revolution, these gases have been increasing in concentration in the atmosphere - which affects the global temperatures. When the temperatures rise sufficiently, they melt the permanent ice-formations on the northern and southern poles of the earth - which means extra water in the ocean - which will flood the coastlines of all continents. That means most of the earth's best cities will be affected by it. Maldives - a whole country - might become submerged if this goes on. 

This was a broad outline, now if you truly want to know more, you have to do it by yourself. Because I or anyone else cannot force you to change your opinion, but rather just help you along and hope that you can find the truth by yourself.

text:
You guys should really stop arguing with this guy. He's only using his own experience as proof, so no amount of scientific articles will convince him.

One thing that everyone seems to overlook is that an increase in the global temperature results in cooling, not warming. The fact that no one realizes this is absolutely baffling. When the global temperature rises and causes a large melt of the ice shelves, the ocean temperature worldwide gets cooler. This leads to a shift in the worlds air currents, as is shown recently with the jet stream migrating more south than usual, resulting in a more widespread cold.

Edward, you are really, unknowingly, proving the rest of the peoples points by arguing a colder climate.

tl;dr: Global warming = Colder Climate

text:
¬†@Edward Dongres¬† We know that global warming is happening based off of changes in weather patterns and overall climate changes, including temperature, humidity, etc. from across the world that we have observed and recorded over time.


The reason why it is considered to be an issue that we need to address, is that within the next 100 years, if we refuse to look for a proper solution to at least curb the rate of change, will cause these negative consequences for humanity: exposure to the sun and the elements will be very inhospitable for humans to live comfortably; many plants and animals (which we need to use as nourishment among other things) will be unable to adapt quickly enough to survive, which will drastically reduce the available resources to maintain food supplies for the general public; the oceans will rise which will cause a sizable portion of our overall land mass to be uninhabitable as it will be underwater; drastic changes in weather patterns (which is already happening at an alarming rate) which will cause frequent natural disasters to occur; air will become more difficult for us to breath (you could probably soldier through it if you didn't have any bad habits in life, though). There are more, but those are the bigger ones.


As far as anecdotal evidence for the contrarian opinion, such as record low temperatures or places freezing over when they haven't in a very long time, that is actually apart of global warming. All you have to do is understand how weather works, which I can give a brief summary here for you: all of our weather is based on two key factors: air pressure and humidity, which is to say, how much air is in a given area compared to surrounding areas and the amount of moisture that is in the air. Heat (say, from global warming) has a direct effect on both. Weather patterns occur based off of air movement and the density of water in the atmosphere.


I hope you learned this in grade school, but in case you didn't or you have forgotten I can remind you: rain comes from the "Water Cycle", evaporation -> condensation -> precipitation. Sound familiar? Water evaporates when there is enough HEAT to warm the water from its liquid form into its gaseous form. It then floats into the air because the water molecules are lighter than the air around it, and it will continue to rise upwards until condesation occurs. Condensation is when water molecules group together and slowly begin to form back into a liquid form. This occurs because as the water molecules travel upwards, they move high into the atmosphere where it becomes colder and colder due to less surrounding atmosphere.


Ok, quick side note: heat causes molecules to become "excited" which causes them to vibrate faster, which causes them to move away from other molecules; cold, or the absence of heat, obviously has the opposite effect: molecules slow down in their frequencies, which makes it easier for them to stay close to one another.


Ok, back to the water cycle: so, since it is becoming colder as the water vapor rises in the atmosphere, its molecules slow down and start grouping together more easily. This is condensation. And when they finally group together enough, they reform into a liquid. Now, I am going to assume that I don't have to explain or prove gravity to you or the fact that liquid water weighs more than air... so, assuming you know at least that much, you should have an understanding of how precipitation works. The molecules condense and their density is greater than that of the air around them, and gravity then pulls the liquid water down as precipitation. I know, I explained it anyways. But I feel like I have to be extra sure with people such as yourself. Now, I have explained in depth how precipitation works, and how heat OBVIOUSLY not only affects it, but is quite literally the driving force of it; so we can move onto air pressure.¬†


So, the other weather phenomenon that you notice besides precipitation is the wind. Wind is when air moves from one place to another. So, how does that happen? When there are differences in air pressure (the amount of air within a given space) between two locations, they naturally want to even out. To witness this phenomenon, all you have to do is check your tire pressure. Tires have air in them, and they require a lot more air per square inch (PSI) which is literally the measurement for air pressure. When you check your air pressure, you are more than likely using a simple tool that you place on the tire's valve that makes a small stick pop out that has various numbers written on it. When this occurs, it is due to a high air density (more air in a given area) rushing out of the tire to even out the air density outside the tire. How much force is exerted when this occurs gives you a rather accurate sign of how much air pressure you currently have in your tire, because the more air that is in the tire, the more air will try to rush out to even out with the lower air density outside of your tire.


OK, almost done with the lesson here: heat has a similar effect on air molecules as it does on water; which is to say, it causes them to become excited and expand by placing more distance between the molecules. So, when air is heated, you cause changes in air pressure, which causes changes in weather patterns, more specifically, you are causing more wind which leads to more storms such as hurricanes and tornadoes. When the overall temperature of the planet goes up, the differences in temperatures in different areas may remain relative to each other (i.e. Canada will still be colder than the U.S.) but they are still increasing in temperature relative to their previous norms (i.e. Canada is warmer in general than it was previously).


Now, this overall warming does not prevent or negate cold weather at all. In fact, it causes more extremes to occur during seasonal changes (more wind & more precipitation). Wind chill causes the effective temperature to be less than what it is. If you have more wind (due to more changes in weather pressure due to more changes in global temperatures) then you have more wind chill. Same with precipitation. More heat causes the cycle to occur with greater frequency because water is evaporating at more constant rate


NOW, if you wish to have a discussion, debate, argument, or whatever on whether or not humans are contributing to global warming and by what amount, that is fine. Have that discussion, hold a debate, make your argument. BUT, the evidence that global warming is in fact occurring is so overwhelming and so obvious to anyone who understands grade school environmental science, that this FACT is not up for discussion.


There IS NO debate.


You have no argument.

text:
Let us take the conspiracy angle

A majority of scientists write papers saying that humans are causing unsustainable climate change.
There are then 2 possibilities:
1) They are doing their job as unbiased as possible
2) Someone is paying them to write biased papers
I reckon the green energy sector stands to benefit from man made climate change, so let's say they are the best culprit for this possible buy-out.

A small minority of scientists write papers questioning the source of climate change, arguing that it's a completely natural occurrence.
There are two possibilities:
1) They are doing their job as unbiased as possible
2) Someone is paying them to write biased papers
I know for a FACT that oil, coal and gas companies can avoid regulation if there are no environmental side effects to their energy production. They actually have huge environmental impacts (spills, strip mining, earthquakes) without global warming, but that's not the point. They stand to benefit if climate change is all-natural.

In the clip, Jon Stewart points out the top 3 campaign donors to one of the congressmen on the committee: Murray Energy, Koch Enterprises, and Peabody Energy. All three work with fossil fuels, all three are better off if climate change is all natural. Of course, just because someone stands to benefit from something doesn't mean they made it up, but Stewart points out something else. "If scientists could be bought, they'd be making it rain in nerd town". Or, more professionally, if most scientists were corrupt enough to take money for biased papers, these companies would have bought them (they are all very politically active). If you think that companies wouldn't mess with science, remember that tobacco companies paid for research saying that smoking is healthy.

I'd reckon the Koch brothers alone could out-bid the green energy sector, considering how much more energy we derive from fossil fuels than all renewable resources combined. So, any scientists corrupt enough to exchange biased papers for money would probably flip to the all natural camp. HOWEVER, we see that a vast majority of scientists have not flipped. Either the green energy sector is vastly out-bidding the biggest conservative donors at a rate of 99:1 OR the scientists releasing papers that support the claim that climate change is man-made are not corrupt. 

In fact, the non-corrupt scientists still have a huge incentive to overturn man-made climate change. Scientists, like anyone else, love fame. The great scientists in history all got there by making a new claim. Darwin figured out natural selection, Newton figured out motion, Einstein overturned Newtonian motion. All of these guys are famous, they went against the science of the time but survived the scientific rigor. If a scientist finds definitive proof that humans don't cause climate change, and all the other scientists accept their findings, they will become famous. Therefore, scientists have incentive to disprove man made climate change. Climate change or no, there are still plenty of research grants for studying atmospheric temperatures, so saying that they perpetuate a theory just to get grants is disingenuous. 

The corporate money suggests that, if scientists are corrupt, they'd sway towards all natural. They do not. Scientists have a vested interest in proving established ideas wrong, yet the community hasn't accepted any of all natural hypotheses (remember, the scientific community accepted Einstein and Darwin relatively quickly). I conclude that there is no conspiracy to say climate change is man made rather than natural or not happening at all. If there is no conspiracy, the majority of scientists are most likely correct: the climate is changing and it's mostly our fault. 

So what of the scientists who claim it's all natural? Some may be bought by fossil fuel companies, but I assume some are also unbiased. Climate data is finicky and even rigorous testing can often yield definite outliers. The slim minority of climate-change-skeptical scientists may have mostly this outlier data. However, since the vast majority of scientists agree that climate change is our fault, by the rules of scientific research, that's the best we know about our climate. We cannot base policy on scientific theory alone (the closest thing to a fact that anything can get to in science) because very few things reach that status. If we base our policy on "there's a slight chance this isn't true" we can't use science for anything. We do the best we can with what we have. Therefore, if we still hold to the Enlightened era ideals we were founded on, we should enact policy to curb climate change until the climate science community reverses its consensus.

text:
No one says that the climate hasn't changed. No one. What they are saying is that the RATE of change is at levels never before experienced. The amount of carbon in the atmosphere is increasing much faster then it ever has.¬†
We know this because we can test ice cores that have "captured" versions of previous atmospheres. In the last few hundred years or so, the amount of carbon in the atmosphere has begun to change like never before and it coincides with when we started burning carbon, so no, it is not a big goddamn leap.
They also made models which predicted the changes we are currently seeing. So not only can we measure the changes that are happening, we were able to accurately predict these change and the impact they would have and what will continue to happen in the future.
You also state that Carbon Dioxide is part of the life cycle, which of course is true, but what you don't seem to understand is that too much will destroy the life cycle. What you need to understand is that Venus has a temperature of 870* F. It is not that hot because it is that much closer to the sun - it is because of the green house gas effect from an excess of Carbon.¬†

text:
Because the rates are far faster than natural change.¬† Nature rarely skyrockets CO2 levels at the rate that fossil fuel burnoff has resulted in.¬† We have had elevated CO2 before, sure, but this is a huge increase in a short time, a sort of "redlining" of the world climate engine.¬† It is entirely unnatural for coal, petrol, et all to be hauled up and burned en masse.¬† This absolutely has a chemical effect.

The stuff you send into the air has consequences, whether that is convenient and immediately obvious to you or not.¬† This may not be a problem for you right now, but your great-grand-kids may very well curse you if you let it happen, as it will not just mess up the shoreline, but wreck the world economy and cultural status quo, and likely result in mass starvation and wars.¬† If you don't mind damning your descendants to hell on earth, just keep your head in the sand and keep insisting that just because you cannot see it now, that it is not real.

text:
¬†@D Nguyen¬†
Indeed, tho it leads to a very closed-in view of life which one may regret as one gets older.¬† Selfish desires definitely tend to predominate unless one realizes the importance of "it's not about me", a fact many never learn, which is why utopian-based gov't models tend to fail.
author: CliventheTraveller

text:
¬†@CliventheTraveller¬† Sorry, but I take issue with what you are saying about CO2 levels.¬† To say that¬†"Nature rarely skyrockets CO2 levels at the rate that fossil fuel burnoff has" is a fact you cannot prove.¬† In fact,¬†historically- there have been a few very large volcanic explosions that spewed out CO2 levels that dwarf anything mankind has created.¬† And those are¬†only the ones we know about,¬†our¬†historical knowledge as it pertains to this issue does not go back very far.¬†
We don't give enough credit to nature's ability to balance things out.¬†¬†I realize that today's leftist filled propaganda¬†has been very effective at getting well meaning people to believe these things to be facts.¬† But while there may be no denying that we are experiencing a current trend of climate change-¬†mankind's impact on it, and it's ability to¬†stop it from happening are¬†issues that are very debatable and are not agreed on by the scientific community in general.¬†¬†And if you really thought about it and looked at history- it would not be considered irrational or selfish to think that the¬†Earth is capable of sorting out this issue on it's own.¬† In fact, one could surmise that attempting to curb this "problem" could very well create a whole slew of problems that we didn't expect- because we just didn't know¬†enough about what was happening and we just jumped in there thinking we could fix this¬†so called problem.¬†¬†Did you ever wonder if climate change was a bad thing?¬† Historically, one could argue that there were times¬†of great prosperity when the earth warmed.¬†¬†And, interestingly enough- every time the Earth has gone through a warming period, eventually it went to a cooling period as well.¬†¬†The Earth is far more capable of controlling itself than we are.¬†¬†I'm of the opinion that it's best to leave nature to do it's thing.¬† When we¬†develop the ability to control weather patterns, the jet stream, volcanic eruptions, etc.- then I will worry about mankind's impact.¬†¬†But then again- when we learn to do that, we won't have to worry about something as trivial as climate change, now will we?¬†
author: grajmahal

text:
¬†@grajmahal¬†
It is worth noting that whenever a volcano erupted, things DIED.¬†¬† Also, global CO2 levels did not raise that substantially for any of those, unless the eruptions of those resulted in global mass extinctions.¬† If you want to point out the ones that did raise CO2 so substantively, I would, again, just like to point out:¬† GLOBAL MASS EXTINCTIONS.

No one is saying the world climate would not self-correct, only that humanity probably would not survive in any recognizable form.¬† It also might take a very, very long time to naturally fix itself to any levels that would be useful towards human comfort.

Sure, nature can sort itself out, but your dead children's children might not appreciate that nature is sorting THEM out.

Ducking your head in the sand is a fool's paradise.¬†¬† No amount of laissez-faire nonsense will stop the waters from rising from increased greenhouse effects resulting from very high CO2.¬† Eventually, the world was going to warm anyway, but it is best for humanity to not help it along right now, given the infrastructure changes that will arise once water levels change much more.¬† Hurricanes wreck economies; what happens when the very seas overrun nearly ALL major industrial centers?¬† Political upheaval, wars, famine, disease.¬† Not pretty.¬†

On this, we agree: let nature happen naturally.¬† That means reduce our hyper-elevated CO2 emissions.¬† The alternative is that humans get "corrected" out by the global ecology, just like any other aberration.
