We may just deserve what is coming.¬†
author: Duong Nguyen

text:
Global Mass Extinctions- I think not.¬† There were plenty of volcanic eruptions that did not cause mass extinctions- but they have created chaos in the atmosphere and disrupted the global climate.¬† In the early 1800's there was a large volcanic eruption- didn't cause mass extinction, but it did force the climate eventually into a mini ice age.¬† Not only that, there is pretty sound evidence to prove that sunspots cause more fluctuations in the global climate than anything we do.
Look, dude- the point is there are far more important issues to tackle than something that is not really in our control.¬† I'm all for important environmental issues, but ones that we can do something about.¬† Climate change is not one of them.¬† A "fool's paradise" is believing anything left wing nutjobs feed you about this issue.¬† The sad thing is it really takes away focus from real solutions to real problems.¬† Of which nobody on the far left or far right want to be solved.¬† Why?¬† Because they both profit from it.¬† Common sense solutions to real problems does nothing but make the majority happy, and that does nothing for extremists.¬† They need chaos in order to make any headway to advancing their agenda.¬†
Now if you want to talk about how we can eliminate destructive non-native fish species from our rivers- I'm all ears.¬† If you want to talk about how to make sure the Siberian Tiger doesn't lose all of it's natural habitat- you got me.¬† But to focus monetary resources and time on a non issue like climate change- forget about it.

http://www.wmo.int/pages/mediacentre/press_releases/pr_1002_en.html

We have problems aplenty that could be solved NOW, if folks at the upper end decided charity trumps personal profit.¬† Those in the lower brackets oft cannot even afford adequate food, so cannot significantly contribute to solutions, and those with means to make changes quite often do not, unless forced to.¬†

These problems will, however, be uncontrollably magnified if more than half of our cities are at least partly underwater, given that global seawater levels WILL rise with greenhouse warming.¬† Why ADD to our problems?¬† All of the issues you raised will be pointless if we let the whole package go bad.¬† Native and non-native fish species may BOTH migrate away with changing avg temperatures.¬† The Siberian Tiger's natural habitat will be unrecognizable, even if we save it, due to climactic shifts; tho some animals can adapt to such changes, most large, apex predators cannot so easily adjust.¬† If the whole structure shifts, any gains w/regard to the patchwork issues you raise will be negated wholesale.¬† Just because you WANT to disbelieve hard data of CO2 levels not seen in 800,000 yrs, when the climate was very, very different, does not make it go away.
author: CliventheTraveller

text:
And now you're talking about "hard data"- exactly what is this "hard data" that you are referring to.¬† Obviously this "hard data" was obtained by World Meteorological Org in conjunction with Doctor Who and his Tardis?¬† Exactly how did we get the "hard data" on CO2 levels from 800,000 years ago?¬† Come on, man- if you're going to try and throw out statistics- at least have the common decency to actually state a number.¬† You're just listening to BS rhetoric spewed by people that are trained in the art of PR and spin.¬† The historical data is just a guess- nothing more.¬† Don't you realize that our technology has improved, thus our ability to detect what is in the atmosphere is much more acute than it ever was.¬† Why do people always fall for this garbage?¬† You have to think a little when you're being told this nonsense.¬†
Here's a statistic for you- according to Forbes, Al Gore has made over 300 million dollars since leaving office.¬† If you do a little digging, you'll see he is heavily invested in mainly environmental based companies.¬† He has millions invested in Cap and Trade, most of his "green" investments have billiions of dollars in lucrative government contracts.¬† He is at the center of a huge industry that relies on misinformation related to climate change.¬† The PR campaign centered around this issue has gone from ridiculous to absurd.¬† The last 5 years the standard spin has been "most scientists agree" that climate change is occurring.¬† Remember when they used to call it global warming?¬† Well, they don't say that anymore because most scientists don't agree that global warming is occurring.¬† Rather, they agree that the climate is CHANGING.¬† Who doesn't believe that?¬† For the record, most scientists do not agree that climate change is occurring due to manmade CO2 emissions.¬† Why- because there is no "hard data" to prove it.¬† In fact, its quite the opposite.
author: grajmahal

text:
¬†@grajmahal¬†
You seem to have a hard time accepting that we can bore ice cores from a million yrs ago to see CO2 mixing levels.¬† It is very hard data.

Most scientists I have read did not call it global warming; that tended to be a media spin on it, as the media tends to simplify and sensationalize by default. ¬†

Where is the proof of your assertion that "most" scientists do not believe the CO2 levels are significant?¬† Faux News?¬† If the WMO chairman posts something based upon data analysis, it seems likely that some amt of actual analysis has occurred by multiple parties.¬† Science's results do not flow from one experiment, but from the ability of MANY parties to REPLICATE RESULTS from observations on the same subject.

Maybe Al Gore invested in the environment because he sees it actually being a real issue, based upon facts presented to him?¬† He is hardly a scientist, but maybe he is just backing what he feels is a good horse.¬† Logic has certain paths; just because someone you don't like backs something you refuse to believe in, does not make it a conspiracy.¬† Sometimes it just means they saw the writing on the wall that you refuse to see.¬†

This reminds me of the fellow who lived on Mt. St. Helens and resolutely insisted it was all a gov't scare; that the mountain was fine.¬† Then MSH blew and he was gone.¬†¬† It is not those who deny today who will pay, however, but their descendants, if the seas rise.
author: CliventheTraveller

text:
I did not say that most scientists agree that CO2 levels aren't significant.¬† I said that most scientists do not¬†agree that climate change is due to manmade¬†C02 emissions.¬† There is not overwhelming consensus as "pro green" advocates suggest.¬†
And yes, I have a hard time accepting any of the historical data.¬† Please help me understand how boring ice cores tells you anything about atmospheric C02 levels.¬†
And since we're on the subject, tell me how elevated C02 levels are the one defining factor that drives climate change.¬† On top of all of that- do we really know if climate change is a bad thing?¬† All valid questions.¬† And before you tell me about all the things that are going to happen as a result of this supposed threat- let's not forget that if we are indeed causing rapid climate change, isn't it possible that nature could correct it just as fast?¬† My prediction is at least as good as yours.
With regards to Al Gore- I look at it like this.¬† If he was a man of his convictions, if he really wanted to convince the naysayers- he wouldn't be banking his investments so heavily on something that he has historically had a lot of influence on.¬† To me it amounts to insider trading- he is creating a PR campaign that has clearly provided financial incentive to himself.¬† That right there is not something I would do, it's against what I believe, and forces me to distrust anything he has to say regarding the matter.¬† He, along with a whole lotta other profiteers have made sure a lot of funding has gone to making their point.¬†
And as to your last point- I could certainly make the same analogy about your viewpoint.¬† You are so blinded by what you believe- that if you were wrong it would have just as much a negative impact on your life as well.¬† All of that time and energy and money on what could very well be a false flag would be wasted when a tragedy that could have been prevented is left by the wayside.¬†
Quite frankly, I think I've had a very open viewpoint regarding this issue.¬† I am not afraid to see definitive evidence that we have a problem.¬† I just haven't seen it yet.¬† On top of that, one can historically look at what happens when societies follow false beliefs- and one can be worried that extremist viewpoints are often the cause of the failure of civilizations.¬†
author: grajmahal

text:
¬†@grajmahal¬† "I did not say that most scientists agree that CO2 levels aren't significant.¬† I said that most scientists do not agree that climate change is due to manmade C02 emissions.¬† There is not overwhelming consensus as "pro green" advocates suggest."

There is fairly consistent consensus among scientists not on an energy company's payroll.


"I have a hard time accepting any of the historical data.¬† Please help me understand how boring ice cores tells you anything about atmospheric C02 levels."

The ice traps the gases after they mix w/seawater (water leeches the CO2 from the air, and then the water later freezes) and leaves them undisturbed for vast amts of time in a pristine environment.¬† This is a condition which less remote mediums rarely provide, as such would get disturbed more often and the samples' material ratios would be polluted.

¬†
"And since we're on the subject, tell me how elevated C02 levels are the one defining factor that drives climate change."

It is not, just as cyanide is not the only thing that can kill you, but it will in sufficiently high doses.¬† Who said C02 was the only factor?


"On top of all of that- do we really know if climate change is a bad thing?"

If it requires a massive restructuring of land use, movement of entire cities, loss of arable land, etc, it may be neutral for Earth, but bad for humanity.


"let's not forget that if we are indeed causing rapid climate change, isn't it possible that nature could correct it just as fast?"

One cannot dodge a (supersonic) bullet as easily as a fist.¬† Humanity is fast-tracking the change process.¬† Earth will rebound, but don't expect it to do so in a timely manner that will work out for human survival.¬† The body is great for adjusting to hostile environs, but if you jump in a volcano, don't expect to live.¬† You need water to drink, but get locked in a full water tank, and the very material you are primarily made of will kill you.¬† Humanity is CAUSING AN EXTREME in the balance of gases.¬† Extremes tend to be bad.¬† Rocks fall on people all the time, but that does not make one justified for dropping boulders off bridges onto cars passing beneath, just because it fits your schedule and lifestyle.¬† It is a matter of not hugely increasing natural forces too much in one direction.¬† Don't tip the boat if you don't HAVE to.


"My prediction is at least as good as yours."

Your prediction of the relative validity of your prediction is based on false premises.


"With regards to Al Gore- I look at it like this.¬† If he was a man of his convictions, if he really wanted to convince the naysayers- he wouldn't be banking his investments so heavily on something that he has historically had a lot of influence on."

Wow.¬† So you should never invest in something you believe in and are familiar with?¬† Somehow, I suspect Mr. Buffett might disagree.


"To me it amounts to insider trading- he is creating a PR campaign that has clearly provided financial incentive to himself."

That's not how insider trading works.¬† It works by getting insight into how specific companies are going to do business in the near future, based solely on their own, closed-door internal operations, as opposed to just predicting market forces, which SHOULD be done before investing.¬† Creating a PR campaign is called ADVERTISING, btw: valid tool, last I checked.


"That right there is not something I would do, it's against what I believe, and forces me to distrust anything he has to say regarding the matter."

Or rather, because you likely vote the other way, you inherently distrust anything he says, so choose to believe at variance with observed phenomena and the judgement of a great many very learned specialists who study the raw data at great length.¬† It's called "responding with denial to a cognitive dissonance."


"He, along with a whole lotta other profiteers have made sure a lot of funding has gone to making their point."

Welcome to politics.¬† SOP even BEFORE the last ice age.

¬†
"And as to your last point- I could certainly make the same analogy about your viewpoint.¬† You are so blinded by what you believe- that if you were wrong it would have just as much a negative impact on your life as well.¬† All of that time and energy and money on what could very well be a false flag would be wasted when a tragedy that could have been prevented is left by the wayside."

Loggerheads.¬† And I am fully in support of fixing the problems you refer to.¬† Let's start by not giving foreign govts disguised as businesses (multinational corporations) a free run around our laws and taxes.¬† That way, we might have the local resources, and the legal leverage, to actually get worthwhile ecological, human rights, and economic changes put in place, and kept there.

¬†
"Quite frankly, I think I've had a very open viewpoint regarding this issue."

And that IS your viewpoint, which I feel is rather focused on obstructing any other PoV.¬† Let me guess. .¬† You feel you have an open popinion, and. .¬† "Fair and balanced" is the motto of your primary news source?¬† Specifically, your blinders relate to the next point:


"I am not afraid to see definitive evidence that we have a problem.¬† I just haven't seen it yet."

Here is where your "open mindedness" falls flat.¬† We have an unquestionable measure of CO2 rate increase, yet you question it, simply because you refuse to believe its relevance, likely due to not understanding the process and, probably and more importantly, not WANTING to.¬† Raw data needs interpretation, but some needs very little interpretation at all.¬† SKYROCKETING levels of C02 in a geological blink of an eye is not vague.¬† CO2 is a greenhouse gas.¬† Even if you would like to see warmer climes, or would like Mother Earth to wink at us knowingly and put a magical band-aid on us sticking a knife into her, the process reaches critical mass at some point, after which it cannot be stopped for a very long time.¬† Once the ride starts, you're on for keeps.¬† That is the problem.


"On top of that, one can historically look at what happens when societies follow false beliefs- and one can be worried that extremist viewpoints are often the cause of the failure of civilizations. ?"

"Extremist" well describes choosing to support disruption of the environment so that a very select/small group of individuals can gain money and power, while the rest of the populace must deal w/the result of that disruption, all the time categorically denying the relevance of all data showing the harm this path causes.

You know what also gets folks killed?¬† Maintaining status quo while the world is burning.¬† Nero actually didn't do it, but the GOP does.
author: CliventheTraveller

text:
"There is fairly consistent consensus among scientists not on an energy company's payroll".

Good point- only problem is, it's the same problem on the other side of the coin.¬† Plus, there are a ton of energy companies that are profiting heavily from the green movement.¬† I'm not totally against that, as I think it's a good idea to diversify resources.¬† But not for the sake of climate change.¬†¬†

"The ice traps the gases after they mix w/seawater (water leeches the CO2 from the air, and then the water later freezes) and leaves them undisturbed for vast amts of time in a pristine environment.¬† This is a condition which less remote mediums rarely provide, as such would get disturbed more often and the samples' material ratios would be polluted."

interesting.¬† I'll certainly research that more.¬† Still seems to be questionable as to it's accuracy, but I suppose it's better than nothing, right?¬† Unfortunately, it still amounts to something a little better than a guess.¬†

"If it requires a massive restructuring of land use, movement of entire cities, loss of arable land, etc, it may be neutral for Earth, but bad for humanity."

Hmmm, since you like to look back at history, I wonder why you failed to recognize that past warming periods for the earth amounted to very favorable conditions for human civilization.¬† And funny thing is, this historical evidence is quite a bit stronger as it was data recorded at the time it was happening.¬†

"One cannot dodge a (supersonic) bullet as easily as a fist.¬† Humanity is fast-tracking the change process.¬† Earth will rebound, but don't expect it to do so in a timely manner that will work out for human survival.¬† The body is great for adjusting to hostile environs, but if you jump in a volcano, don't expect to live.¬† You need water to drink, but get locked in a full water tank, and the very material you are primarily made of will kill you.¬† Humanity is CAUSING AN EXTREME in the balance of gases.¬† Extremes tend to be bad.¬† Rocks fall on people all the time, but that does not make one justified for dropping boulders off bridges onto cars passing beneath, just because it fits your schedule and lifestyle.¬† It is a matter of not hugely increasing natural forces too much in one direction.¬† Don't tip the boat if you don't HAVE to."

Wow, this quote is filled with a bunch of analogies that are just plain ridiculous.¬† You are not equating equal scenarios here, my friend.¬† My predictions are based on false premises (according to you), but your predictions are based on really bad analogies- you don't see the irony here?

"And that IS your viewpoint, which I feel is rather focused on obstructing any other PoV.¬† Let me guess. .¬† You feel you have an open popinion, and. .¬† "Fair and balanced" is the motto of your primary news source?"¬†


I'm not obstructing any other viewpoint.¬† That's the problem with extremist viewpoints from either the right or the left.¬† Once someone brings a counterpoint, or has a question that is sound and rational- extremists instantly say they are being obstructed.¬† Sorry, bud- but your lefty ways are extremely apparent in this little diatribe.¬† Especially with your attempt to classify me as a Fox News junkie.¬† Sorry, although I'm often accused- I am not the conservative you think I am.¬† I merely look conservative from the extreme left.¬† It's unfortunate you don't realize how far left you've gotten.¬† My primary news source does not come from television.¬†

With regards to the whole Al Gore and insider trading rebuttals:¬† You're right, it's not insider trading.¬† Probably a bad choice of words there.¬† But it's still not right to politically create a market, and then profit from it.¬† That's a typical conflict of interest issue that many politicians seem to partake in.¬† Typically, this is a Republican tactic, but obviously it's not exclusive to them.¬† And yeah, PR/ marketing/ advertsing- all "legitimate" tools.¬† But it's all BS.¬† I abhor political PR campaigns- they are always filled with half truths and outright lies.¬† That, my friend, is what is wrong with it.¬† It can't be trusted.

And in the interest of making this whole debate just a little bit shorter, I will only make this comment with regards to your wonderful lecture at the end:

You are obviously coming at this from the complete opposite end of the spectrum that I am.¬† To say that I have blinders on is completely disingenuous.¬† I certainly think there may be cause for concern somewhere down the line.¬† But I really don't think we have a clear picture of the situation.¬† Plus, I don't think we have a real solution.¬†

I do think we have some real problems in the world that need a far larger part of the world's attention- this issue should be left to scientists to hash out.¬† I really wish the politics of it all was not influencing it so much.¬† And that's from both sides.¬† You can say I'm ignorant and I'm gonna watch it all burn down around me.¬† But, I on the other hand feel that the other issues are what will cause our downfall.¬† Climate change and our desire to solve it is the blinder, my friend.¬† Climate change is the boy who cried wolf.¬†
author: grajmahal

text:
¬†@grajmahal¬†
Apologies for not getting back to you sooner.¬† I have been stuck in the back end of beyond with just a flip phone, and have to head back to it even now (just in civilisation for a quick break), but am glad to see you are open to research on the ice layer data.

I do use analogies quite a bit; I am a lateral thinker, and connections and similarities are my main mode of thought.¬† I also tend to bring a sledgehammer to YT discussions on that front, as more subtle analogies tend to go over the heads of most folk.¬† Glad to see you are not one of them, and I will think of better ones for next time.¬† I d/n feel they were inaccurate analogies, just extreme examples, tho.

I agree that politicios are politicos across the board, but the specific stances of some are "the lesser evil", IMO.¬†¬† PR is also flase-faced feces: we agree on that.¬† Every side plays its angle.

My main point is that we CAN adress the issues you bring up, as well as the ever-increasing impact, in the long term, of climate change effects from increased greenhouse gases (among other things).¬† We have the ability to fix nearly all of it RIGHT NOW, but we prioritize to spend on far more selfish and destructive pursuits, for the most part.¬† We do not, for instance, NEED to be addicted to oil.¬† That is an economic choice, far more than a practical one.¬† We have had hi-milage, alt fuel, etc etc vehicles for decades, but it would have cut onto profit margins.¬† That our economy is based on the petrodollar is the problem.

Anyway, I have to get back upstate and will be incommunicado for another week (hopefully I will be able to afford at least a proper smartphone again soon).¬† Next week I will be able to reply more fully, but I wanted to thank you for your more measured and polite latest reply; it was refreshing.

Best wishes for now, Graj!

author: Edward Dongres

text:
¬†@Edward Dongres¬†
No - the scientific community did not predict a new ice age in the 70's. TIME magazine hyped a SINGLE study that suggested that particulate pollution was causing cooling (which it was, by blocking solar radiation). But even then, a majority of climate scientists thought we were warming. The theory goes back nearly a century, and by the 1950s it was considered the most likely scenario, but we did not have the evidence to have confidence in that prediction. We now do.

TIME Magazine is not a good source for science.

The predictions about oil were also correct, because they were based on known reserves at the time and estimated rates of consumption. None of them claimed that we would not find new sources of oil - simply that it is a big risk to take - gambling the entire world's energy economy on oil we had not found. Had we not found large new reserves, we would basically be out of oil. Again - read what the scientists ACTUALLY said!

As for the "hiatus" - there is none. There was one anomalous El Nino year (1998) which was MUCH hotter than previous years. But every year after fell back into the pattern we had been seeing - '99 hotter than any year except '98, 2000 hotter than 99, and so on until we finally topped 1998 in 2014.

To call one exceptionally hot year followed by years that were consistently hotter than all the years before that one a hiatus is like getting a 90 degree day in March in Michigan, and concluding that summer is not coming because it's been cooler every day since that one.

And yes - it is very cold here in Muskegon, and guess what? We know WHY! It does not change the overall global temperature. But disruptions of normal air and even sea currents are one possible effect of warming, and guess what? For the past two winters, the Jet Stream has taken an unusual path, bringing cold air from the Arctic down to the Eastern USA. meanwhile, temps in the US southwest have been above normal. Of course we can't conclusively tie ANY single event to GW but the incredibly cold winters that we ave had for the past two years fit the theory perfectly.

Did you know that a warmer Earth could bring a mini ice age to our region and western Europe? They made a really stupid, scientifically inaccurate movie based on that - you know, what you would call science! It played all over the world!!!

What you see outside your window is a tiny segment of the bigger picture. There is nothing stupider than cherry picking data.

text:
Maybe Jon Stewart should educate himself about some things.

The IPCC (where almost all "climate research" comes from) is not a research organization, but a government organization primarily pushing government interests. And sadly, scientists have to conform to the opinion of whoever fund the research (which is mostly government) and also need to conform to the general consensus to get their work published. Remember that it was general consensus that the earth was flat and saying otherwise could get you killed.

"Global climate change is an accepted scientific phenomenon". But even scientists publishing for the IPCC don't agree on the amount of human effects down to a scale of no measurable effect at all.

We are in an ice age. Lets repeat that. We are living in an ice age, which is defined by the fact that we have permanent ice on the poles. The current ice age is coming to an end at a time scale of thousands of years. Ice ages existed in long cycles all through earth history without any human interference. The human effect via CO2 on global temperature is not proven at all. CO2 has been 5 times higher than now throughout large parts of history with flourishing plant and animal life. If CO2 would be half of what it is now, plants would STARVE to death.

Every single climate model by the IPCC fails to predict climate. They keep on changing the models including highly controversial and totally unproven factors and are still unable to make predictions which come even close to measurements. The scientific method can only lead to the conclusion that the models are wrong. So any conclusion made with these models is unproven at best.

Then on the topic of ice. When ice is swimming in water and melting, the effect on the water level is zero. The water even shrinks when the ice water is warming up (towards 4 degree Celsius). All of the north pole ice is swimming. A considerable amount of the south pole ice is swimming. How much glaciers on land are there compared to the polar ice? If the atmosphere is warming, it can hold MORE water. So again, warmer temperature does not automatically lead to much higher sea levels. And even if it does, so what? Who cares about Holland (sorry when you live there, but its not the end of civilization).

Also, more than half of the ice on the north pole is melting and regrowing on a yearly cycle (not exactly yearly as it it not due to seasons but pacific and atlantic streams). So if the polar ice melting would be a catastrophe, then we would have a catastrope every year or so already.

text:

It may happen sooner or it may happen later. It's pooled and cumulative knowledge of our best minds applied in a way that's self-correcting.¬†

The only way to get around that is to believe in a massive conspiracy theory. Sorry, but I'd rather take the Occam's razor and point out that it's pretty fucking unlikely. People have way too much inane shit to do to coordinate such an effort, and fairly little to gain from doing so.

As I said before, almost nobody takes scientific findings as "word of god" - well, unless the data is extremely strong (theory of evolution for example). Your straw man isn't even a good one. Why do you keep clinging to it?

author: Rodger D

text:
¬†@Rodger D¬†¬†Where exactly did I blame scientific method is "flawless"? (Nothing ever done by humans is flawless. That's just good old hyperbole there.) Also, the method and the results are two completely different matters, but those "contradictions" are part of the method. You know, as in the science being self-correcting. Over the time the view that surfaces is likely to represent reality (or whateverthehell scientists might be studying at the time) fairly accurately. The sort of consensus view may be wrong as fuck, but that's still the best guess anyone was able to make by looking at the data available.

Contrast that with politically motivated views: it's A-OK to pull stuff out of one's ass, and call that "values" or "moral choices" or whatever.

Guys, understanding the scientific method on this basic and superficial level is not exactly rocket science. Please at least¬†read that fucking wikipedia article.

text:
Holy shit let me break this mechanism down to you: Humans use fossil fuels to generate electricity and make plastic, roads, candles, etc. by burning them. Burning fossil fuels releases carbon dioxide and water vapour because fossil fuels contain hydrocarbons(compounds containing hydrogen and carbon). Carbon dioxide and water vapour are greenhouse gases. While it is natural to have a fluctuation in carbon dioxide levels and to have greenhouses gases in general, rate of release of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere is very much greater than rate of absorption of carbon dioxide by carbon sinks such as forests and oceans, causing GLOBAL warming(because of enhanced greenhouse effect). In fact, global temperature has risen over 2 degrees Celsius greater than that before 1850. This leads to CLIMATE change which means change in weather patterns over a long period of time, like more drastic storms or hurricanes etc.¬†

And seriously? "Scientists today have done nothing but replace the church. It used to be that people would not question the church's authority and judgment." Do you not know how science works??? Whatever theory a scientist has come up with is subjected to vigorous peer review. Scientists' authority is frequently questioned, your comment being an example. Science is a self-correcting industry whose advice is hardly heeded by corporations to make more money(refer to: C.C. Pattinson's campaign against lead poisoning). By your logic, I bet you don't believe in evolution too since you don't see it everyday.

text: Mate no one is worried about the current state. It's fine still. That's the whole idea with going sustainable now, not wait until it's slightly... less comfortable, and then maintain that level. The global average warming isn't even 1 degree, and that's global, you can't perceive that by traditional methods aka observing your environment because 1. The change is small 2. It's global 3. Weather plays its part 4. Your nerves aren't quite as accurate as scientific tools, nor is your memory. Same goes for people saying climate change is obviously real cuz of recent weather effects. There is no immediate correlation. The point is, we are fine right now, but both very fundamental science as well as recent statistical research concludes that the climate is indeed steadily getting warmer, with natural flunctuations since the earth is a chaotic system. No one is saying this is 100 %. Science is never 100 %, possibly math, but we're still dealing with extremely high probabilities. What people are worried about is the acceleration of climate change which will lead to a far more dramatic change, therefore it's preferable we start living slightly more ecologically now, instead of thinking about it when not only 50 % of the species out there but something like 90 % have gone extinct, and we're facing an ecological, economical and global disaster. Alarmists can make it sound like it's going to happen today, which is not the case, but that doesn't mean that your winter disproves a global, well-researched trend, nor that there wouldn't be any drastic ecological catastrophes already taking place.¬†

Whatever belief systems people have is highly cultural, even though there will always be people who seldom question or critically examine that which they have an open mind towards. I'm just curious how proving WW2 or ebola is possibly when we take this to a philosophical level, questioning not only the scientific method, authorities and sources of information, but also the technology. Ebola is spiraling out of control in media, it's far more sheeple-propaganda-scaretactics than climate change, and there is no way for us to travel back in time as of now, we are simply taking the word of history books, elders and tradition as truth. These may be easier-to-explain examples, or to "prove", but there's tons of stuff which relies on the exact same research and methods that brought us whatever we know about climate change, phenomenon that no one questions, yet they are even harder to perceive.¬†

I'm not saying climate change has to be real because media and climate experts say so. As a matter of fact, tons of politicians, energy/oil companies and reporters deny climate change as a whole, and they have the same senses as scientists so why would their worldview be more biased? I too live in a country where we are literally freezing our asses off atm, yet still the theory of climate change makes perfect, rational sense to me, because 1. I have experimented with greenhouse gases, 2. I've witnessed ecosystems fall, 3. I've read research on both sides, pro-and against climate change, and the only uncertainty seems to be whether or not we are actually the primary cause, even though the latest IPCC put a lot of weight on issuing that (even the researchers speaking up for oil companies and scientists famous for denying climate change say that global warming is a thing, but humans aren't causing all of it) 4. As I said, global warming isn't a catastrophe, but a prophecy. Right now = fine, somewhat normal, cold winters, no super extreme conditions that can be directly correlated to climate change even on a glboal level, melting glaciers and arctic ice yes but still it's nothing stunning... that's the whole problem. If it was doomsday, people would have no problem seeing it in their backyards without being researchers and scientists themselves, people would have no problem reacting to the physical threat (as with your comparison to terrorism or something which is easy for all to see as a threat)... but that's not the case. It's progressing extremely slowly for a single human being, and insanely fast for a geographical cycle, which isn't one bit natural. Neither me, or you, can sense it, because it's not that out of control yet, but it will be after hitting tipping points if we actually aren't going to do anything about it. This generation will deny/procrastinate it, the next may get worried, 5 generations later they will suffer.¬†

Even with all this, it's possible it's just a myth, we don't know. That's the thing, the world is too big for us to be all over the place, or see patterns in weather/climateconditions and keep track of em in our head and thus prove climate change right/wrong. I too am skeptical about this whole thing, but at least for now I have enough basic science + research background to consider this theory highly logical and probabilities high, at least when opposed with somewhat vague "evidence", even if you want to call it common sense.

text:
¬†@interneti¬†¬†There have been reports... The same people who are researching climate change are well aware that the polar ice caps on Antarctica are getting bigger, it's empirism, it's science, and it's logical if you knew the least about how the world as a global system works. In the north we are seeing the opposite trend, and several glaciers that have been permafrost for hundreds of years have already melted, which could be a coincidence, of course, but there are very few glaciers actually expanding, besides Antarctica. And here we go with the sheep again... questioning climate change is good, and the mainstream science sure, but preferably one would look it up, read it, understand it, and THEN question it with either rational arguments or empirical research which shows otherwise, like a true skeptic... but quite honestly, your own eyes are fallible, and what you can perceive of the global world is so limited that simply because you aren't feeling threatened by climate change isn't a strong enough argument to disprove the theory as a whole.

Naturally, you have the right to that belief and to stating your opinion (and preferably with some common sense and respect, without being called an idiot for thinking otherwise as you pointed out, as certain renowned scientists and free thinkers have been called idiots or even killed for thinking differently in the past, which you also pointed out at least indirectly), but with this vauge arguments this discussion/debate isn't really going anywhere and you're not going to change anyone's view. You might also want to quesitons these reports claiming glaciers are growing bigger, if you claim to be extremely-antisheepish. Honestly, the whole debate is sheepy, only of the other color. Only the skeptics remain whatever a sheep isn't, and with skeptic I mean skeptic, not denialist, not alarmist, but neutral, objective and rational. You also laugh at Raj for naively thinking scientists are under some kind of oath or incapable of lying. I see far better reasons for politicians, media, entrepeneurs, companies, all of those to deny climate change, as I see reasons for them to agree with it. Now, this is a global phenomenon, and there are scientists all over the world who (despite this globalized world) have done independent research, and they have come to more or less the same conclusions. Scientists aren't paid well, unless they are public figures too, and many aspire to become scientists because of their genuine interest in the subject, not to get a job, not to become rich or famous, but to learn more about the world. There will be ones who succumb to corruption if someone offered them a lof of money for right out lying, but whatever they report is also peer review and reviewed by other scientists, and criticizable and examinable by all of em, and to say every scientists in the world is corrupt is beyond paranoia, it's far from realism and as it's possible, it's skeptically speaking highly unlikely that such a conspiracy has existed for tens of years.¬†

As for your temperature estimates, just because a pole is melting doesn't mean it's molten, and just because the world's climate is changing doesn't mean it has changed. We are still in the early stages or this accelerating trend, and the world is a chaotic system, only the future will tell if the projections and predictions and models will correlate with the "truth", and to which degree. At the moment we can only speak of probabilities, and of statistical significance. You have also spoken of reports and about similiar trends in history like the extreme weather which was mentioned, amongst other things, but without any clear reference to a certain article/research/point in history. For avoiding being a sheep, it's good to question those too, and if, despite being the questioning type, using them to support one's own arguments, it's preferable to link them as well, for more credibility.

Anyway, these are youtube comments. They will seldom lead to or account for much. And it's full freedom of speech and trolling, without having to follow any set of rules or prove anything by any methods. Sometimes it's fun, sometimes it's frustrating. Sometimes one wants to make a change, get one's own opinion heard, but there are people doing it in real life at this very moment with full power, so we can all relax and leave this at discussion, unless one is truly engaged with this issue. As such, I think we can keep the discussion casual and leave death threats and judgement of other's intellect where they belong: in the US Congress. lol jk, but still, no need for that.

Remember this is but reflection and speculation until we reach the future. (unfortunately any consequences of not acting can't be really proven either, so it would be kinda more rational/safer to just play it safe and do what we can to stop climate change, whether it's going to happen or not) ;D

Have a good day everyone.

¬†@interneti¬†¬†That argument isn't quite valid, with teacher vs researcher vs stupid expert... First of all, saying all climatologists are ignorant, lying, corrupted, don't know their field, greedy, incompetent or anything else is grotesque generalization and won't really have any significance as an argument in this discussion. Secondly, this is a global phenomenon, studied worldwide, not a US-only conspiracy of democrats looking to re-distribute the economical resources. Where I live, scientists, namely researchers, get shit salaries and are well aware of that as they are making their career-choice during studying. It's a sacrifice, to study what they are curious/interested in, they consciously give up on living a luxurious life, if anything, they can get lucky and become famous or perhaps win a nobel prize, but that's it, their salary is still low and far lower than our High School teachers, who have to study a minimum of 6 years to become one (ofc researchers have to study far longer, another con).

Another thing is that it's fairly well known that our universities are incapable of hiring all of these experts, resulting in people who have studied for over a decade to end up unemployed. This is not something they learn after they graduate, this is something people know in High School. That + the fact that everything is peer reviewed says, according to my logics at least, that they are more likely to know what they're talking about, more devoted and knowledgeable in their field and less prone to have set out to exploit/fool/gain on others than the vast majority of people, especially big companies that exist solely for financial gain and are going to lose a lot more than any scientist could ever dream of owning (at least here) if we abandon coal and oil. It doesn't require a book of any sorts to conclude that if there is a conspiracy somewhere, it's far more likely to have been started by huge companies with tons of resources, rather than a global science community working and concluding the same things independent of each other. Oh, and I'm quite sure these huge companies have a lot more people employed than there are climatologists in the world.¬†

¬†@interneti¬†¬†¬†@rambodude142¬†¬†This whole discussion is based on opinion or internalized believes, for both sides, and even though most of the rhetorical methods used (insult, judging other's beings and intelligence based on their belief, just general edgyness) aren't taking this anywhere, nor are they what one would consider intelligent (whatever that means), I still think it's important to listen to the other side and what they have to say without instant denial, and if all there is to hear is empty words or digressing generalizations, then it's quite obvious the whole discussion is pointless. However, for both sides of this generally very polarized discussion, there are no openminded people, only "not sheeple" questioning and criticizing the opposite side but never their own. Neutrality and objectiveness, which IS SCIENCE (therefore, without having researched this personally it's reasonable to go with what science is saying, because in an ideal world, this is the method and principle) is often nowhere to be seen in these discussions, nor have I seen any legit arguments or references so far (maybe at the start of the chain, was awfully long ago lol)... Skepticality comes with philosophy, and most skeptics (note; not denialists, skeptics), also considered among the most intelligent people out there, listening to the rationality of their own mind, questioning all and then concluding based on empirical evidence and own thinking... more or less all of them agree with Climate Change being a phenomenon taking place, and you will need some rather hardcore arguments or reasoning to convince these thinkers otherwise.

But yeah, nothing is certain in this world, even science is always about uncertainty and probabilities, significance, therefore it's not very fair to instantly ¬†judge the opposing side without actually arguing against them, listening, and if needed admitting they have nothing to say to disprove X or Y or even reaching some kind of compromise. One can't be a free thinker (and therefore independent of these authorities interneti speaks of, "brainwashed", ironically not questioning his own side or even senses, bubble, worldview at all... not "brainwashed" to internalize and conditioned to believe it all, but having rebuilt one's own worldview) without considering opposing views as a possible truth, but concluding that one is far more rational or likely, and therefore, while aware it may not be an absolute truth, have that as a base for one's worldview.

But common sense also says that the people publically trying to deny climate change have a lot to win by doing so, and conspiracy-theories are the main tools of a denialist, not a skeptic. Also, one can find proof for anything by googling: just because it's there, doesn't mean it's true. And for real, even if this was uncertain, if it's a question between money and the future of life... absurd, how people can be so obsessed with material goods, luxury, comfort, money, consuming, 3rd party recognition... if there's something stopping action and development, it's the socionormative view on success, which almost no one seems to question, and sorry to say but the US is completely brainwashed by this right from birth, by parents, society, media, school, everything. Some places are actually getting slightly colder, or stay the same, scientists recognize this. Most people here in Canada believe scientists rather than websites that can't back up their claims. 
Note, I'm NOT saying that all scientists are always right or that some aren't corrupt or anything, but general scientific consensus is extremely important.

text:
I forgot to link some data, sorry about that. Fortunately for this discussion, I'm currently attending the University of Minnesota Twin Cities as an Honors Physics major, taking a biogeography class to fill some requirements.

Okay, Balsam Fir, which thrives in average temperatures around 35 degrees Fahrenheit, already has lost about 40% of its range in the past 50 years. ¬†Admittedly, this is also a popular tree for pulp, so I'll throw this result out, despite the fact that MN doesn't have a large enough logging community to get rid of that many trees. ¬†It should be noted that the range is projected to decrease by 76% over then next 50 years from its current using current projections of climate change.
What about the Paper Birch, another tree that likes temperatures around 36 degrees Fahrenheit? ¬†Well, it's lost about 50% of its range in the past 50 years, and from there is expected to reduce about another 85% in the next 50 years. ¬†I could continue, but you won't believe that, so how about some numbers? ¬†Let's use the average temperatures of Minneapolis over the past 120 years. ¬†Fortunately, I've already done the calculations for you, but you can spend 15 minutes to do the math yourself if you'd like. What I've come up with is that, over the past 120 years, average winter temperatures in Minneapolis have increased by 4.152 degrees Fahrenheit, or 2.307 degrees Celsius (a huge amount) and summer temperatures by 4.056 degrees Fahrenheit, or 2.253 degrees Celsius. ¬†I'll also mention that I got this data from the National Weather service, which is not affiliated with any "suspect" scientific formats (although with your paranoia, I'll just assume you'll throw these facts out and ignore everything I put out there). ¬†But, at least those who are still willing to see reason/debate, at least you've got someone willing to do some math for you.
author: Joe Michalski

text:
+interneti Ah, I think I'm getting an idea of what OC is talking about. I admit I've only read a few comments so idk if I'm off; I'm also only a college student that takes some science classes for enjoyment (ya know, since I think what happens in the physical world I live in is important). What I've mainly seen is a misunderstanding of climate change and a very strong, but blind, belief in religion. 1. The correct term is actually climate change. The temperature is not generally increasing, but temperatures have actually become more unstable. Around my NJ area, anyway, summers have had years of being hotter and winters being colder, for example. However, climates vary naturally. So in a span of 30 years, variations don't mean much. However, if you were to look at a chart of temperatures spanning at least 200 years (to include the Industrial Revolution) you will see that there have been increases in overall temperatures for a few periods, higher than they had been. (Ofc, due to increased CO2, a greenhouse gas, increasing how much heat the Earth retains from the sun, etc) In addition to temperature, more CO2 leads to more acidic oceans, less corals, and less habitats for marine life. As for ice melting, more of the concern for melting ice is typically on land, as Jon said. Yes, the ice would expand as it melts, but an overall heating of a huge mass such as the oceans, would lead to a great increase in sea level rise in itself (although is isn't much of a concern at the moment since different parts of the ocean have been heating and cooling). As glacier lakes or glaciers on Greenland, for example, melt more water will be entered into the oceans and lead to sea level rise. This rise can lead to changing the environments of coastal areas. 2. I respect the thought of believing in a religion. What I cannot agree with is believing in one side and completely shutting out any outside ideas, especially if they've been scientifically proven. 
As a side note, drastic changes such as a noticeable loss I'm temperature-dependent trees in your area is unlikely. The Earth is big, these causes have long term effects. They may start as something small like ocean acidification, less corals being able to use the bicarbonate they need, less of that habitat for marine life, altered food chains, (maybe less food for the growing population). The point is, climate change is mainly a deep concern for future generations, if not the next one. Either way, early action can be very beneficial with enough of a scientific grasp behind it.

text:
And you still haven't answered my question nor shown any knowledge of anything relevant. ¬†I also live in the Upper Midwest, namely Minnesota, and it's been getting warmer faster during the summers. ¬†Slightly, but it's still somewhat noticeable. ¬†Last year's winter, the most brutal in years, was a nasty outlier, but an outlier nevertheless; this year is more indicative of the trends. ¬†In Minneapolis, the temperature remained around 54 (?, I don't actually have the temperature data for this year yet) degrees Fahrenheit (average). ¬†The first day of sub-40 weather was in early November, which is extremely late in the year. ¬†As I said, that's what I've observed; your observations may be different, but that's the nature of the world. ¬†Also, unless you're a machine, the reliable sample size of human memory is very small, usually 1 or 2 years; outside of that, we always remember "the worst;" the worst snowstorm, the coldest year, the warmest summer, etc. ¬†That's an atrocious sample size, especially considering how long the Earth has been around, approximately 4.2 billion years. ¬†The percentage of time that your memory takes up is literally insignificant; in percent, that's 2.381x10^-8%.
Considering that, it's shocking that the 1933 Dust Bowl is the worst drought in the past 2 millenia, measured from tree rings. ¬†Yes, some trees live for over 2000 years. ¬†Using that data (which I actually have seen, not in person, though), it's possible to tell that the 1933 drought was nightmarish for those trees. Or then there was the fact that, if my data is correct, and the data from ice cores is correct, the temperature change we've seen has happened before, but never so damn quickly. ¬†We've increased the temperature of the earth by about 2 degrees Celsius in a manner of 120 years (again, using my gathered data), which is almost 10 TIMES faster than some other eras of temperature change. ¬†And that's a minimum of ten times, mind you.

text:
Climate change is real, but man-made climate change is not. There are certain impacts of our carbon emissions like the high temperature in cities like Mexico City (which is one of the hottest cities in the world as a result), and acid rain which poses serious consequences to health and infrastructure. But there is no evidence for the long term impact of man made climate change because the theory is still new. there are many climate scientists that are do not believe in climate change. one example is Timothy Ball. This link has a list of other scientists with the IPCC that are against climate change¬†http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_scientists_opposing_the_mainstream_scientific_assessment_of_global_warming.
I would like to reiterate that I do believe the planet is getting warmer but I believe it is caused by the natural climate cycles, fluctuation in energy released from the sun, the earths position in orbit, and methane releasing wild animals such as cows and termites. ¬†I also believe that there are more important issues that should be tackled which are just as much a threat to future generations and have much greater impact and relevance to current generations such as obesity.¬†

text:
Look, America doesn't even really do socialism - not like, say, modern Europe - and so saying socialists have brainwashed everyone is a fallacy because American society is incredibly right wing.
I advise you to look at all the other nations that recognise global warming exists. Ooh, look, what's this? Norway, Scotland, Germany... Iceland ffs, they all acknowledge it. Just because it's cold, doesn't mean the earth overall annual temperature is not rising. It's not something you can recognise by feel, because the human body is a bad vessel at measuring changes of temperature, especially something as small as a fraction of a degree over the entire surface of the earth. Oh, that can't hurt us, it's only a small amount? Yup, yes it can. If I recall, if the temperature increases by just two degrees celsius, it could cause trouble. The permafrost of the tundra will thaw, releasing methane into the atmosphere (demonstrated in a Louis Therox documentary I believe) and add to greenhouse gases. This will speed the problem up incredibly, as methane is a worse pollutant than CO2 by a factor of four.
You are simplifying things incredibly, interneti, in an attempt to dumb down an incredibly complex scientific phenomena that you have decided doesn't exist because you could make a snowman and found it good fun. It is slow in terms of our lives, but it is very quick in geological terms, and could pose significant risks to sustained human inhabitance of the world in the future, as the greenhouse gases (such as chloroflourocarbons or CFCs) breakdown Ozone (O3) which protects us from harmful ultraviolet light, and reflects light (and the heat energy of the said light) back towards earth instead of releasing it out of our atmosphere.
I hope this educates you slightly, but I doubt you will. Some people are so stuck in their beliefs politically and otherwise, they can't see reality.

text:
If Stewart were interested in informing the public about the truth, he'd be bringing up chemtrailing by various governments. First it was denied, then it was being continued as "supposedly" helping to increase the Earth's atmospheric albedo (light reflectance value), but in reality what this whole program was doing all along was retarding the nocturnal infrared radiation back into space, thereby increasing the net temperature of the planet.

This issue has been pointed out on numerous occasions by scientists willing to speak out, but conveniently avoided by other scientists who need to focus on political correctness to support the US and other countries' illegal militarization of weather around the world through programs like HAARP.

Even though the foundational work for these atmospheric technologies was first envisioned by Tesla almost 80 years ago, it wasn't initially embraced until the mid 1980's and put into full swing under the first Bush Administration, which not so coincidentally was when we started to see the real major changes in our climate.

So, while everyone is going after the low-hanging fruit to find a cause for global warming or climate change, the globalists are ¬†intentionally using this playing field to posture themselves for the next wealth grab ........ and douchebags like Stewart are totally oblivious to what is going on. Perhaps when the feds and other governments STOP applying aluminum and barium salts to the atmosphere, maybe the scientists might have something legitimate to measure, but as long as the globalists continue to push global warming under the table, they will continue to be the ones to offer us a solution. Even though the globalists have been in managerial control all this time, they want the guys at the bottom of the ladder to pay to clean up their mess ........ and remember, they all became incredibly wealthy while they turned a blind eye to polluting and overheating the planet.

text:
The IPCC safe maximum CO2 was 350 PPM.
The current measured level is 400 PPM.
The industrial 8 hour limit is 5,000 PPM
Divers get short breaths at 5% = 50,000 PPM.
Convultions occur at 10%, noone survives 20%
.
So we have exceeded the 'safe' limit,
but at 1/100 of what we directly perceive, it remains invisible.
Thats not a red herring, its central.
Thats not climate science, its politics,
the question is travelling in the wrong direction.

text:
There seems to be a general misunderstanding in this comment section on how Archimedes' principle works, so here we go:

First part (and in this context the only important part) of the principle:
Any floating object displaces a volume of water equal in weight to the object's mass.

So a ship (=floating object) with a mass of 1 ton displaces 1 ton of (fresh)water, which is about 1 000 square meters (a 10mx10mx10m cube of water).

The same applies for floating ice: 1t of floating ice displaces 1t of water = a 10x10x10 cube of water.
So if floating ice melts, 1t of ice becomes 1t of water ... with the already mentioned volume of 10x10x10. The waterlevel wouldn't rise in that case, which is the point the guy in the committee makes, and he would be right if it would be as simple as that.

HOWEVER, this doesn't take into account the difference between seawater (=water that is "salty") and freshwater (which is what floating ice is made of) and many other factors like water temperature.
Seawater is denser/"heavier" than freshwater.
Because of this difference in density of the sea water and the ice, the increase in volume would be about 2.6% of the volume of the melted ice water.
Globally, if all the floating ice on earth would melt, the sea level would rise ... 4cm.
So the committee guy is actually wrong.

The major contributers to the rising sea level would actually be water temperature and the ice on landmasses (like Jon Stewart mentions).

text: There's something called the "Green House Effect" basically, think of the Earth as a giant greenhouse. The CO2 emissions(both from natural and artificial sources) that go into the atmosphere, trap incoming solar radiation because CO2 is what scientists call a "greenhouse gas". This "Green House Effect" is what keeps the planet from freezing in the cold vacuum of space, and why too much CO2 is a cause of concern. By the way, different¬†gas compounds¬†interact differently or don't interact at all with the different kinds of solar radiation entering the atmosphere. As¬†a¬†result, the effects of atmospheric compounds interacting with solar radiation¬†can(with varying degrees) have direct/indirect impacts on life, climate or both. Hope that helped.

text:
It seems to me that the "By the People, for the People" mentality is what led to the formation of committees in the legislature in exactly the same way it led to a trial by peers; the decision makers are placed in a position of responsibility and it becomes the job of experts to present their cases before this group in a manner than everyone can understand, and from the evidence presented the committee/jury will decide the course of action. But I prefer a system like Germany's; it's not a jury of peers trying you for murder, but a council of judges--each and every one of which is an expert in the field, but with differing interpretations--much like our Supreme Court. The lawyers are then there not only to out-speak one another, but convince these people who are their academic superiors that they're right.

But I guess requiring our lawmakers to be anything other than lawyers would take a lot of money away from Ivy-league schools, pump it into more technical institutions as the rich buy their kids degrees, and overall lower the quality of American education even more when they're too stupid to pass and businessman daddy gets pissed.

text:
From the Daily Caller:
"Not all scientists agree that global warming is man-made. Nearly half of meteorologists and atmospheric science experts don‚Äôt believe that human activities are the driving force behind global warming, according to a survey by the American Meteorological Society.

The survey of AMS members found that while 52 percent of American Meteorological Society members believe climate change is occurring and mostly human-induced, 48 percent of members do not believe in man-made global warming.

Furthermore, the survey found that scientists who professed ‚Äúliberal political views‚Äù were much more likely to believe in the theory of man-made global warming than those who without liberal views.

‚ÄúPolitical ideology was the factor next most strongly associated with meteorologists‚Äô views about global warming. This also goes against the idea of scientists‚Äô opinions being entirely based on objective analysis of the evidence, and concurs with previous studies that have shown scientists‚Äô opinions on topics to vary along with their political orientation,‚Äù writes survey author Neil Stenhouse of George Mason University.

‚ÄúThe result suggests that members of professional scientific organizations have not been immune to influence by the political polarization on climate change that has affected politicians and the general public,‚Äù Stenhouse writes."

Stewart is a lazy thinker and an ideologue who skews information to meet his needs, unfairly "skewering" anyone who dares to have an independent opinion.¬†

text: ¬†@KMartresse76¬† The ice has already displaced its weight in the water. 1 kg of water will freeze into 1 kg of ice. Although the ice weighs the same, it will take up more space when frozen, because it is less dense (Which is why it floats). author: Matt Brown

text: The 'representative' probably got this from the fact that much Arctic, and a fair amount of Antarctic ice is already 'in' the water, and that this factor was neglected in some early sea-rise models, so newer models show a slower rise with a lower peak than some of the old ones (though I'm sure he got the idea much mangled by a string of Aides playing 'telephone') Of course, we should remember a given volume (not weight, sorry Matt Brown) of ice in an ice shelf displaces considerably less than the same volume of ice broken loose and floating free. (the shelf's a giant cantilever).¬† It also loses volume when it melts (surprised he didn't mention that) but since it's glacial Ice that's been compacted over millennia, a whole lot less than your average ice cube. Then again, once it warms up from near freezing to equatorial temperatures that water will have expanded again, not enough to notice in a glass, but definitely enough to notice in Amsterdam where about 7 million people live maybe 2-3 meters above present sea level.

author: Daniel Nadgrabski

text:
¬†@Daniel Nadgrabski¬†
¬†Sorry, but you are wrong about water expansion.¬† Like any other matter, water expands as it's temperature is increased.¬† That is the main factor in the projected rise in sea level.¬† A 2 minute google search will provide you with lots of links where the contributions from various sources are quantified.¬† Melting glaciers is the smallest and themal expansion is the biggest.
This part is not controversial at all, its just basic physics a high school student can understand and test in the lab.
author: Bob Lake

text:
¬†@Bob Lake¬†¬†Yes, i know that. Its my problems with english to explain it properly. I read what i wrote, but i was too lazy and that was my fault to put it into a correct way. Nevertheless, Thermal expansion ¬†for me is not really the reason to worry about.

BTW costs 1 minute of google, if you know where to look for it:
While still the last IPCC report of 2001 assumed that the majority of sea level rise was caused by the thermal expansion of sea water in the 20th century, more recent studies are partially different results, especially for the second half of the 20th century. So for the last 50 years, about 1.4 cm sea level rise per decade were attributed to the eustatic sea level rise. Compared to the overall increase of almost 2 cm / decade, which means that the expansion of sea water by heating plays a much smaller role than the increase in mass of ocean water through water supply from the mainland. The question of what the main reason is for sea level rise in recent decades, however, remains a subject of scientific debate.

I never was on a "high-school" , because im not american. ;) Here we have a little bit different schools. Greets from germany.

Here are my sources:
IPCC (2001): Climate Change 2001: The Sientific Basis. Contribution of the Working Group I to the Third Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, Cambridge and New York 2001, Chapter 11

Lombard, A., A. Cazenave, P.-Y. Le Traon, and M. Ishii (2005): Contribution of thermal expansion to present-sea-level change revisited. Global and Planetary Change 47, 1-16; Miller, L., and B.C. Douglas (2004): Mass and volume contributions to 20th century global sea level rise, Nature 428, 406-409

Cazenave, A. und R. Nerem (2004): Present-day sea level change: observations and causes. Reviews of Geophysics 42 (3), 139-150; Miller, L., and B.C. Douglas (2004): Mass and volume contributions to 20th century global sea level rise, Nature 428, 406-409

You're obviously well informed on the topic :)

What you say might be true if that is the case, but easiest way to test this is to get a very long, thin cylindrical container and put in a large piece of ice that fits and floats and see if the water level increases, since it would be hard to see in a large container.

Density is only useful here to explain that since salt water is more dense than normal water, more ice is not submerged in salt water. Most of this has to do with buoyant force and volume not submerged (Which density is a part of, but only explains that the bouyant force will be greater)

author: Bob Lake

text:
¬†@MasterDinomutt¬†
I am very sure that I am correct, I am a scientist, (read lots of physics and chemistry)¬† Here is why.

Archimedes' principle indicates that the upward buoyant force that is exerted on a body immersed in a fluid, whether fully or partially submerged, is equal to the weight of the fluid that the body displaces.

So the crystalline structure of ice contains only two things, water and air.¬† Therefore the weight of the ice is equal to water that it contains, and this is equal to the water it displaces. So an ice cube displaces water equal to its weight, thus, 6.6 percent of an ice cube floats above water, but when it melts it fills the hole it floated in.¬†

IF an ice cube floats in salt water, approximately 10% is above the water line.¬† This is because salt water is more dense, and so the volume of salt water needed to equal the weight of the ice cube is smaller.¬† Thus, when THIS ice cube melts, it raises the volume of water because the density of the fresh water contained in the ice is less than the salt water it was floating in.

If you don't believe me, test it.¬† Make up two glasses of water, one salt, one fresh, fill them to the brim, add ice so they flow over, then wait.¬† The salt water glass will overflow as it melts, but the freshwater will not.

¬†@Mee Eee¬†¬†First of all you didn't read my comment fully, because what you just stated was what I stated, except I stated it more concisely.

2nd, you are partially wrong. Ice will displace water equal to the volume that is submerged. You can't displace a weight, that doesn't make sense. You displace a volume, but yes okay that volume has a weight.

3rd, What I am saying is that this is only true for so called "freshwater" if the volume when it melts is equal to the volume below water.

If you take any object, and it floats in water, and put it in a container with water, part of it will not be submerged. When you then submerge that object (with your finger or something) you will see the water level rise since more volume is pushing away more water.

Experiment is not really necessary, but one way to see the difference is not to put it in a regular glass. You need a very thin container with water and a very large piece of ice that fits in the container so you can actually see if the water level rises. You won't see the water level rise if you use a huge container with maximum surface area because it will be displaced across that surface area.

Sources: PHD in Physics

text:
¬†@*****¬† Actually, water does not freeze at depths because it is most dense a few degrees above freezing, so as it gets closer to freezing it "floats" to the surface.¬†

Ice is a crystalline structure, it does not need "air" to form, it needs a "seed" to begin the crystalline structure, once a crystal forms others will cling to it and start a chain reaction.¬† Thus, pure water will not form a crystalline structure (ice).¬† There are also many versions of ice, depending upon the pressures exerted upon it during its lifetime, or formation, the crystalline structures can vary greatly.

As for your water in the freezer in a glass jar, try this.

Get a really really strong jar, and try to freeze the water.¬† The internal pressure will prevent ice from forming despite it being below zero Celsius (32 F).

text:

How green house gases work. How much additional co2 is being produced because of human activities that wouldn't be there if it wasn't for us. Correlations between rising co2 and rising temperatures. Analysis of other planets like Venus who's atmospheric composition has been analyzed and found to be high in green house gases and has a high planetary temperature. There are boatloads of reason beyond a measurable rising global average temperature.

Tell me how you think they are hiding this supposed manipulation in there peer reviewed publications. Every scientist who reviews the work produced by the scientists who are pointing out that climate change is happening would get a huge amount of funding for disproving human effected climate change, so it is in their interest to find anything like what you are baldly lying about happening.

You are ignorant of how we have come to the conclusion that humans are accelerating climate change far beyond natural levels and you are badly misinformed on how peer review works.

Because I'm well educated on the topic, unlike you, I do know all climate warming events are caused by greenhouse gases, not only co2. Since I said we compare greenhouse gas levels through change in the past to what is happening now your just calling my names to try and falsely discredit me. Keep your ad hominems to yourself.

Nobody is saying the world is going to be a ball of flange in ten years, except for climate change deniers like you. What climate scientists are saying is that we are changing the climate so fast we are going to cause mass extinction events because of destroyed habitats and badly changed weather patterns. Since humans rely on the environment to grow and harvest food, we are likely to cause a massive decline in food availability causing massive starving in all countries.

You can make all the claims you want about how we know humans are changing the environment but anyone who picks up a metrology journal or looks up the actual data and crunches the numbers themselves will easily see you are wrong.

author: MegaJumpShoot

text:
¬†@MWcrazyhorse¬†¬†As requested: First link is an abstract, second is the full text. You'll have to create a free account for the full text. Worth the time. Lead author is associated with the Carnegie Institute of Washington, an independent scientific organization. This article provides a pretty solid review. Their model is incredibly conservative: the authors avoid making assumptions on future emissions by using current levels of CO2 emissions in their model. Even in that scenario, there would be a mean 1.3C rise in temperature globally from preindustrial levels.

http://dge.stanford.edu/labs/caldeiralab/Caldeira_research/Davis_Caldeira2.html
http://www.sciencemag.org/content/329/5997/1330.full

If you know where to look, the body of literature is out there. Admittedly, it's not terribly accessible for the general public. This article has been cited about 170 times since publication (2010) according to google scholar, meaning that a lot of people in the scientific community are using it. Being published in Science (the journal) also says a lot about the rigorousness and relevance of the article. I genuinely hope that this is helpful.¬†

Also about that comment on temperatures cooling by 1C in the last 500 years: that's likely in reference to the little ice age, a period of global cooling during the Medieval era. Note this was during preindustrial times. Another good read, plenty of good sources around online on it.

Thank you for those links! Very kind of you also to not go straight to the standard insults like some others here unfortunately ofc. did. It seems to be the level of debate. We can blame the topic and move on.

I am reading through it and just to sum up the problem I am having.
#1 we take it as a given in the debate that CO2 is responsible for the 0.6 ¬∞C temperature increase of the last 100 years and will therefor cause a rise in temperature of the stated 1.3¬∞C.
That is not evidence. That is an assumption. Everyone knows we emit CO2. I'd like to see the causal link between the two. As of course temperatures fluctuate.
We are talking ppm here. 400 ppm CO2 is the naturaly occuring CO2 in the atmosphere. Correct?
Excerpt from your links [between 2010 and 2060, forcing mean warming of 1.3¬∞C (1.1¬∞ to 1.4¬∞C) above the pre-industrial era and atmospheric concentrations of CO2 less than 430 parts per million. Because these conditions would likely avoid many key impacts of climate change, we conclude that sources of the most threatening emissions have yet to be built.]
CO2 levels will increase to said 430 ppm, correct? That is 0,003% of the total atmosphere. And yet we as a civilisation are already reaching peak oil and have depleted near half of earth's coal reserves.
What could we possibly burn to actualy increase that above 500ppm?
#2 The article focuses solely on said CO2 (see #1).
You correctly state 500 years ago was a warm period. Temperatures have declined by 1¬∞C since then and we are now reaching the next 500 year naturaly occuring warm cycle.
Yet it seems to be the debate is attributing all of the 0.6¬∞C warming of the last 100 years to CO2. Most extreme here of course Jon Stewart, making fun of the "wobbling" and so on. Why? WTF. Ok he is not a scientist but a comedian and I always liked him so no hard feelings.
But there exist natural cycles of warm periods do there not? And are we not in one?

There is no real point in trying to argue with this person. He/she is just going to - very politely - keep raising more spurious arguments that have long been shown to be false and ask you to help him/her 'understand'. This is just a tactic used by people whose minds closed a long time ago.

The only reason to respond is to counter the claims so other people reading this don't think there is any merit to them at all - and using profanity weakens your argument. That's part of the tactic. They seem nice and reasonable, while the counter argument seems un-hinged.¬†

Most of you have walked right into the trap.

author: Honkler Bear

text:
Averaged over all land and ocean surfaces, temperatures warmed roughly 1.53¬∞F (0.85¬∫C)¬†since 1880. The average global temperature fluctuates every year. However, when you look at a snapshot of the global temperature trend, it's on the rise - particularly since 1970. The main cause? Carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gas emissions from human activities. Overlaying the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere shows a clear correlation with the rise in temperatures. Of course correlation doesn‚Äôt always equal causation.¬†
However, reams of peer-reviewed research, basic physics, the ability to track the specific chemical fingerprint of fossil fuel-driven carbon, and the fact that no models can replicate this century's warming without pumping up carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases in the atmosphere give scientists confidence that human carbon emissions are driving the globe‚Äôs temperature higher. Other indicators such as ocean acidification, increasing deep ocean heat, melting ice and permafrost, shrinking snow pack, and sea level rise further make the case that the additional carbon dioxide is affecting the global climate system.
There are periods when other factors might temporarily slow that rise such as the much-discussed global warming ‚Äúpause‚Äù of the last decade, but the overall connection is clear. If greenhouse gas emissions continue to rise, the globe‚Äôs average temperature is projected to follow suit.

author: helmedon

text:
¬†@*****¬†
Well I am not terribly surprised most countries agree. Though that is of course irrelevant to science or the truth. And I am aware that a also a majority of scientists agree. But all of it is argumentation from authority.
There are scientists who disagree and very little of that seems to be discussed. Peer reviewed yes. And what scientists critical to the global warming/ climate change debate say should also be discussed. In science and in the media. That is the basic idea of peer reviewed. No?
Here is the mediation. Does CO2 affect the climate? Of course. However how much exactly? It is a weak greenhouse gas and the man made portion makes up roughly 0,04% of the total greenhouse effect.
Is that a reason to reseach it and possibly take measured steps to reduce emissions? Sure.
Does it make sense to stifle the debate, ridicule and portray a one sided narrative in the media (rising sea levels, countries potentialy flooded, Ice bears dying, bringing the topic up after every storm or flood)? Imho no. And that is where my bullshit radar goes off.

text:

We are in a warm period. All of that which you mention is to be expected in such.

The climate changes constantly. And not just 4 times a year of course. But in naturaly occuring cycles. Such as the Milankovich cycle see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milankovitch_cycles. In case you haven't heard of it. Feel free to explain to me why that or the solar fluctuation has no relevance. And why some think it is warranted to instead continuosly insult me.
